Majority of why they only recieved 2 stars - the restaurant was not busy at all. It was a little early for lunch (a little before noon) so the restaurant was not packed. We ended up waiting a long time for our bill - and even had to flag down someone to tell them we were ready to pay.

- - - - -

Overall, this place is OK for thai. It's good but not the best. Service is not that great (especially when it's not busy) so come when you have a lot of time to wait. lol.
author: Kat O.

description: The food is amazing, very authentic and it tastes great. Staff is friendly and the atmosphere is good. I only found the tables and chairs a bit to close together so it's a bit cramped. A bit more space and slightly bigger tabled would give you a more relaxed feeling.
author: Tom K.

description: The food here is great.  I usually get delivery to take out. The staff here is always friendly, they are a lot nicer than Osha across the street.  I recommend the crab fried rice, it is delicious and it has big chunks of crab, yum.
author: Daisy L.

description:
Fast, yummy, easy lunch that's reasonably priced and seems to be exactly the same as when I last worked in the area several years ago.  

My favorite dish is the pad prik gluten, the gluten which I believe they make in house.  If you ask for it spicy, you get it, and you can ask for chilli paste if you need a little extra kick!

A good place for a mix of meat-eaters and vegetarians.
author: Jenni S.

description: Ordered Thai fried rice carry out and got a bunch of veggies with some rice. I'm Thai and even told them on the phone to really make it Thai style. Thai restaurants just need to stick to authentic cooking and the customers will come. Few know this and instead feel they must westernize.
author: Dave M.

description: The crab fried rice wasn't bad, I asked for brown rice and they were able to make it spicy as requested. I think it's ok, I had better Thai food, and the papaya salad wasn't OMG good, but it's doable. I think the flavor was a bit more mellow? I do like it though, I think it's a quickie for Thai food that doesn't cost an arm and a leg.
author: Minerva L.

description:
Ok, I've eaten here three times previously and it was always good, service prompt.  Tonight they had a group of 10 leaving when i arrived, got seated and no one came to take my order for 10 minutes.  I finally had to get up and ask for a server.  Then my cold soup came, but no dinner. Finally asked and 20 minutes later it came out.  Shrimp had to be de-veined and shelled by hand.

Sorry, but I know they can do better with by hiring servers with experience and training.

1.5 hours to have a bowl of soup and a grilled seafood special. Sorry Cha-Am, but my time is more valuable than that.
author: Alan M.

description:
A bit disappointing...I had been wanting to try this place out for a while and it was so-so.

When I walked in, the restaurant smelled so good - it smelled like ginger and garlic being cooked together.  As soon as I saw the menu and noticed the Thai BBQ Chicken, I felt like I had to order it.  When my plate arrived, it looked decent enough, but the flavor was way off.  It'd been supposedly marinating in  lemongrass, coconut milk and other assorted spices, but it just tasted burnt and kind of bitter...it wasn't horrible, but didn't taste anything like it was supposed to.  My companion had a Shrimp/Vegetable Green Curry dish and it was pretty good - nothing outstanding.  The Chicken Satay Skewers were pretty good as well.

With Osha Thai now across the street, I'll probably go there instead.
author: Ken G.

description:
Ate here once.

I have this to say:  They no longer carry beef satay, and that hurts my feelings.  DEEPLY.

Why?  because the picture of the beef Satay in the yelp review looks GOOD.

Yes, I am going to try and mark that pic as "unhelpful"
author: Adam P.

description:
I like Thai food. I really do. Especially when I'm in the mood for it, so that's where I think I went wrong with Cha-Am: I wasn't in the mood for it. 

I wanted soup. More specifically, I wanted Pho - the broth, the veg, the savory. So, when my friend suggested we go here for supps, I figured I'd find something in that range. 

Wrong. They didn't have a ton of soups to chose from, and what I selected was probably lovely for what it was, but it was all wrong for me. It was a thick, coconut milk-based, mushroomy, thick white gloop that we quickly nicknamed something really rude and undesirable. I also had a mixed greens salad that was very simple and underdressed. 

But my buddies liked their full-on Thai dishes with chicken, peppers, bean sprouts and  sauces. The service was very good and their beer selection was decent. Next time!
author: Hilary H.

description: Went there for lunch today with co-workers and 3 out of 8 of us ended up sick. I never thought this place was as good as the others but now I'm never going back. Save yourself and go across the street to OSHA Thai.
author: Erin C.

description: Pretty good, but feels overpriced. Not better enough than some of the significantly cheaper nearby Thai places to justify what they charge.
author: Rajesh S.

description:
Can you say SPIIIIICE-AYYYY!!! 

Holy lord, I had to buy a new tongue off the black market after eating lunch here with coworkers. Every dish we ordered happened to be super spicy. And that's NOT a bad thing!.. In fact, this was one of the first spicy Thai dishes I couldn't resist. Every piece of savory prawn, every slice of succulent pepper, and even the white rice was delicious!

Please come enjoy Cha-Am. They don't deserve Osha Thai trying to swoop in and steal any business. Cha-Am has much tastier food and higher quality food at a more affordable price point. 

The only thing lacking: 5-star service. It was more 3.5 star service.
author: Andrew C.

description:
A pretty decent Thai restaurant located right on Folsom St. So it was a bitch getting to there because of the heavy traffic. The decor isn't that bad, the lighting and environment felt nice to me. Sat me and my girlfriend right next to the window where lingering pedestrians look at us eat.

The food, also decent but not to great. I can never stop myself from ordering Pad Thai at a Thai restaurant (but I do anyways), which tasted like I've said so many times, decent. The Spicy Calamari was also pretty good, but I think pricey for the amount they gave me.

Overall it is a decent place, wouldn't mind coming here. The waitresses were nice, but I thought they were kind of awkward because they felt like vultures or crows just passing by your table to see if you needed anything (was just awkward because they were staring so much).
author: Brendan N.

description: I'm a  fan of the crab fried rice and the fact that it delivers to the downtown hotels.  The pad thai mild was spicyyyyyy.  I can only imaging what my friend's medium version was like.  I had the beef shortribs - flavors was a tad too sweet  and the fatty parts needed to be trimmed a bit, but it wasn't bad, still tender and juicy.  Will order from them in a pinch again but maybe will look to Osha's menu just in case.
author: Aileen D.

description: Prefer this Thai place out of any of the ones in the Soma district. The food is served in a reasonable time. The service could improve by the severs checking on me, but I personally don't care because the food is packed with rich flavors.
author: Nestor C.

description: Hot delicious food delivered on a sat night, in less that 30 mins - 1 mile away. Great vegetarian selection!
author: Sneha G.

description: The food here is excellent and it's very reasonably priced.  Also, the customer service is stellar.  Last time I was there, I told them some of my favorite ingredients and they custom made a dish for me not on the menu.  It was the perfect dish.  Really love this place!
author: Chester S.

description: Had the Pad Thai and the Gaeng-Keo-Pak (green curry). The Pad Thai was pretty good considering I can never find good pad thai. The green curry was a little spicy but really good I would recommend it. only downside I ordered for delivery and the delivery guy did not come up to my building at all. He just came and left and after over an hour of waiting I called them and finally got my food.
author: Nina M.

description:
Had the Salmon curry with veggies and rice.
$9.00 lunch special was A-ok.
always crowded at lunch time, get there early or late.


Customer service: always good.
Decor: modern, clean.
author: Bert K.

description:
Had the Pad Himali and they obligingly made it mild for me and switched out white rice for brown rice. However, service is getting worse. When I pointed out old lipstick on my teacup and asked for a new cup, the server gave me attitude like "its not my fault!" . Then he brought me a new cup and asked me to check it for cleanliness, holding it out to me. When I pointed out "this is not my job, it is yours," he protested and insisted that I check it. When he poured tea into it, he hid it from me with his back (he was at a counter) and appeared to pour the same tea into the new cup from the old (dirty!) cup.
This kind of defensive attitude will not bring repeat customers back. We are here for a good experience, not stress.
Despite wanting to help this place stay on its feet, I may finally cross over to Osha.
author: Nan L.

description:
It's decent thai food but nothing that knocks your socks off.  the proximity of cha-am to my couch is way close so when i crave thai food and dont feel like cooking I'll just order take out.  

last night we walked in, ordered pad see ew and pad-prik.  it took a little longer than usual and when the food came out, the owner inspected our containers of food.  strange.  i guess that was for the sake of quality control?

so the pad-prik doesn't come with rice.  i mean, is this a san francisco thing for asian restaurants to charge for rice???  one would think it is an unspoken rule that we have rice with everything!  oh back to the point...a small side of rice will set you back $2.50!
author: Sally T.

description: Great Indian food.  Best somosas.
author: David F.

description:
I know when I eat at Cha-am that I am probably eating Thai food as authentic as Chevy's is to Mexican food.
That is not to say that there aren't tasty offerings at both locations.
I love the mango salad here and their sauteed dishes are pretty good over fragrant coconut rice.
Please don't order the Tom Yung Gung... I'm not saying it has MSG but I shared a bowl with someone and I've never been so thirsty in all my life. I like salty but this was a mess.

Service here is pretty good and the location is clean.
author: Edi B.

description:
Want to get your curry in a hurry? It won't happen at Cha-Am, which is great, because to me that means there's some quality cookin' going down in the kitchen to make my eats as scrump-diddly-umptious as possible.

If portion control is the name of your game, you won't want to be setting foot here. My red curry with pork was a gigantic cornucopia of awesomeness with a side of white rice to soak up some of the extra sauce.

Our servers were so polite, you'd think they were Canadian... or Thai. Are the Thai known for being polite? If yes, the ladies at Cha-Am are spot on. 

We ordered some delectable little deep-fried bites as appys as well. Those were my favourite part of the meal. With a large, spacious dining room and plenty of seating, Cha-Am was a choice spot for our group of 7. And splitting the bill 7 ways proved no problem.
author: Wendy P.

description:
Are you kidding me!? I ordered my food and one hour later it still has not arrived? Wow! I just left hungry and mad. Its too bad I have to give this place 1 star. I used to like coming to this place but not anymore. Its just too bad.

I don't know what the servers and cooks were thinking (if they even were thinking), but based on today's experience, the people who work here are either:

1) Incompetent
    or 
2) Lazy

I would love to know from the owner/manager on what the excuse is for not putting out food in a timely manner.
author: Jason C.

description: Attentive staffs; reasonably-priced food, a bit too dark decor, parking is ok.
author: Joelle K.

description:
I am always a fan of Thai food.  When in doubt, Thai will not fail me.  

Cha Am is located at the corner of Folsom and 4th, right downstairs from my friend's apartment in SF and we 3 girls lazily dragged ourselves out for dinner before heading out for the night.

We ordered:
Crab fried rice (one of the specials)
Pad Thai
Papaya Salad

The papaya salad was super refreshing.  The different flavors and textures help to open an appetite.

The crab fried rice was like regular fried rice with crab meat.  It wasn't bad, but it just wasn't good.  I am usually a fan of duck fried rice but I guess all the fat in duck meat is what puts the flavor in the dish. Crab fried rice was just a little boring.

The Pad Thai was delicious though.  It made up for the lack of flavor in the crab fried rice.  We ate family style so I ended up mixing my fried rice with the pad thai and thought it was scrumptious.

So good we came back for a quick lunch after a long morning at B2B.  We ordered the Papaya Salad, Pad Thai, Pad See Ew and the Chicken dumplings.  Papaya Salad and Pad Thai was still good.  The Pad See Ew was OK. and the Chicken Dumplings were interesting.  They were deep fried so the fried part was good, but I didn't like the soy sauce dipping sauce they had, kind of killed the overall experience of the appetizers.

One of those places you shouldn't go out of your way to eat but if you're ever in the area try it!
author: Grace L.

description:
I'm downgrading my review of this place for 2 reasons:

1) The service has become spotty and inconsistent. It often takes 10-15 minutes to get food served, and this is when the place is *not* busy. Today, for example, we were one of exactly 2 tables which had people. A grand total of 5 people between us. Food took in excess of 20 minutes to arrive. Not good.

On 2 of my last 3 visits, one person at the table got stuck waiting for their food while all the others were eating.

2) "Accidental" overcharging. Today marked the third time that the amount we were charged for stuff was higher than the menu price. One of us was overcharged today. Two of us were overcharged on a previous visit. And on a third visit, two of us were charged nearly twice the listed price for our food.

They'll correct the overcharge when it's pointed out. But the question is: why does it happen so consistently? I get that mistakes happen in a restaurant, or anywhere else. And I'm forgiving of them. But when the same thing happens 3 times? Nope. That's no accident.

This place used to be pretty good. It's a shame that they've allowed themselves to go downhill.
author: Tim B.

description: Not authentic. American-Diner-Thai. Better than eating from a dumpster but hardly gourmet.
author: Vaulte K.

description:
Bad service ! I been a regular to this place since my work place near around,the girl usually work here is nice  and the food was good! But the last couple times my pineapple fried rice and duck fried rice was too oily compare to the other time i been here!
So i been here last night, the service was bad, our food just came out and the waiter ask me if he can take the seasoning away( he tried to get to the other new table) i told him im still eating and some more food coming, we need the seasoning! 5 mins later, he ask me the same question, i said ' im still eating ' 5 mins later, he ask me the third time! Excuse me! Theres two other tables already done with their food, how come you just trying to take the season on my table away! 
Anyway, after we done, i ask for two to go box, he gave me two boxes with no lid! 
Same time, i put my card on the bill and done boxing all my food, seat there and long wait long wait long wait for he to take my card, seem like he just never look at our table,and end up i bought it to the cashier .. Another wait !
author: Angie L.

description:
Quick service for lunch and everything I expected from a decent Thai restaurant.  I got my standby, Pad See Ew, because it's one of the few dishes that isn't laced with onions.  Just yummy beef, broccoli, carrots, and noodles.  

Nothing overly remarkable, but good dependable food.
author: Scott S.

description:
Ordered some take-out from here:
Pad See Ew: excellent
Pad Thai: just ok
Tom Yum Soup: too lemony - not sour enough

prices were reasonable but overall just an ok place ... nothing special.
author: Michele S.

description: Great place. Ordered pad see ew and fried rice the portion was reasonable for the price. The food and the service were great. Ordered a small sour and spicy soup that was also delicious. Would visit again.
author: K R.

description:
The decor was ok but overall dark.  The place was totally empty except for us too.  Bad radio playing also. 
I wish I had better things to say. I really dislike giving such poor reviews, however my food was terrible.  

Pad Thai - not tasty, quite bland
Yellow Curry - tasty, but  too sweet

Nothing tasted fresh. I started getting that ill feeling as I was eating. Maybe I'm sensitive, I don't know, but even the Pad Thai did not make me want to eat it!   Not really desirous of coming back here !
author: JAy J.

description:
Went again with my gf- met the owner who was very nice and very friendly. We just got dessert - coconut drink and mango/sticky rice.

we had alot of fun talking with the owner and staff and enjoyed hanging out at the bar. We even met some of the owner's friends. 

(guys: I even got a peek at Monday night Football)
author: Chris G.

description:
True story.  I was meeting a friend that works at Yelp... We agreed to eat at OSHA THAI.  Across the street from Cha-Am.

This is me... I walk in to Cha-Am... no one is in there... they seat me.  Ask me 3 times if I want to order a drink before my friend shows up.  I cave and order a thai iced coffee.  

Yelp friend txting me:

Friend: Heading to Osha now.  Be there in 10.

Me: I'm there.  It's empty.

Friend: I figured.

Friend: I'm at the front.

Me: where? I don't see you.

Friend: At the front, where are you?

Me: sitting near the front, where are you?

Friend: I'm at Osha Thai on 3rd and Folsom.

Me: Me too... wait... where am i?

Turns out, I'm at Cha-AM across the street... they were very nice... did not charge me for the iced coffee and let me run out to Osha Thai unscathed.  

Someday, I'll try Cha-Am.
author: Frank M.

description: First time going there and got the worst service. I just wanted to grab some lunch to go. Waited 5 mins while the staff seated everyone after me. He took my order, then came back in 10 minutes and said "I am in training, someone else will have to take your order again." That someone else turned away and continued to seat other guests. I walked out.
author: Viola W.

description:
Fact: If you have Thai food at least once a week, your life will be a little better.

Promise!

Since I discovered Cha-Am just a block and a half away from my office building, the quality of my [work]life has improved indeed. I don't quite have the flexibility that many folks do in stretching my lunch break beyond the allotted hour, so I certainly appreciate that Cha-Am can seat me, serve me, feed me and return me even with 15 minutes (walking time) to spare.

Can't say the food here has particularly knocked my socks off, but I've had expensive, showy Thai, cheap 'n greasy Thai, and everything in between. This Thai falls into the last category for being tasty, inexpensive (everything on the lunch menu besides the specials is $7.50), and served up pretty. Bonus points for the plethora of FRESH veggies they include in their basic green chicken curry--at most places you don't get much more than some bamboo shoots and basil leaves, but Cha-Am seems to grasp the value of this important food group. Thanks!

Besides being a trusty meetup spot in SOMA for colleagues or friends during the week, it's also a very convenient location for those visiting the Metreon/Yerba Buena Gardens, Moscone Center, or MOMA. I think it's actually attached to a parking garage. If you drove here (I didn't), double score for you!
author: Kate V.

description: Called to place an order for delivery and they don't even deliver even though it states that they do. In fact the customer rep I spoke with said he needs to check with his boss to see if they deliver.  Horrible!
author: Pea L.

description:
Pineapple Fried Rice.

Great flavor. Not too much oil. Didn't use any yellow curry. No chicken. LOTS of shrimp. Pineapples and cucumber were fresh.
author: Anthony N.

description:
Cha-Am. Ta-Asty. Che-Eap. So not Tre-Endy.

Cha-Am is like the old pair of Hush Puppies in the back of my closet. I know they're comfortable...I know I can slip into them and feel like I could walk around without getting a blister...but somehow, you know the tan suede makes you the anti-fashionista.

I mean Basil is a cooler looking place...and Thep Phanom has all the fancy-looking dishes...even Khan Toke has that rinky-tinky "King and I" ambiance complete with the "please to take off shoe" policy. But Cha-Am is always there with its rather un-cool seventies-style look...waiting to pull me back.

And it does. I usually come here in a group because the dishes feel family style to me. Any time I can get good roasted duck, I go for it...and order the Ped-yang ($9.25) where they bring out Daffy sliced and ladled with a sweet-and-sour soy sauce over mixed vegetables. Now to offset the grease factor - more psychologically than nutritionally - I generally insist on the Pad-pak ($7.50), mixed vegetables in a garlic herb sauce.

They do curries well and since I am an autumn person, I go for green since it is more flattering than red or yellow when I spill it on my shirt. The Gaeng-keo-wan ($8.50) hits the spot since they put the sliced chicken breast in a nice, spicy green curry coconut milk sauce. Lots of goodies in there, too - Asian eggplants, bamboo shoots, long beans, peppers and basil.

I usually skip dessert after such a big meal unless you really, really insist...so the fried bananas in ice cream ($3.50) do in a pinch. Then I waddle out of the place into that good, good night.

FOOD - 4 stars...good, home-style Thai, big portions, decent prices
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...needs a makeover but maybe not...it's part of its dated charm, y'know
SERVICE - 4 stars...fast and friendly...though I think the waitress should hold up the white board with the specials, don't you think?
TOTAL - 4 stars...flavorful & proudly untrendy Thai in SOMA
author: Ed U.

description:
The food was terrific, the service was friendly, and the food came out fast!  

I had their Tom-Ja-K soup, which consists of fresh tofu in a coconut milk, galang, lemongrass, kaffir lime juice, fresh mushroom, and rosted chili...AMAZING!!  I will be returning to try more of their items, I hear their pineapple fried rice is terrific...can't wait!
author: Angela G.

description:
We came here for dinner midweek and found the place rather slow. It's a typical local Thai restaurant and so we ordered the spicy red curry with beef flank, pad thai, and a couple of thai iced teas.

The spicy red curry was delicious! Perfectly seasoned and just the right amount of spicy and sweet. The pad thai was also quite flavorful as well.

They charge you $1.50 for a small bowl of rice and had to order 2 bowls just for the curry alone. Also, the wait was a little long even though we were the only two patrons in the restaurant.

The food is good though, it's close to our place so good neighborhood spot for thai if you are sick of osha or tara.
author: Betty C.

description:
This modest Thai restaurant in SOMA is just a block from my office and I've been for a few times now. Whenever I go, is usually with some coworkers either to grab a quick bit to eat or to celebrate someone's birthday before going back to the office to labor the day away. Of the times I've visited, the food here is palatable. 

On my every visit, I try to order different dishes on their huge menu selection from appetizers, to stirred fried and soup noodles, rice dishes, ala cart dishes and specials of the day so I can sample everything. Among the variety of dishes I tried so far, I am quite satisfied. 

The Green Mango Salad appetizer is made with julienned of green mangos, poached shrimps, mixed green salads, red onions and dressed in a tangy and slightly spicy lime dressing. It is a taste bud teaser and the tanginess makes you hungry for your entrée. 

Pad Kee Mao (Thai drunken noodle) is delicious rice noodles stirred fried in a spicy sauce with onions, bells peppers, Thai basils, and meat of your choice. There is a bit of spice in this dish so stay away if you can't handle or do not like spicy dishes. Apparently this is the Thai version of hangover food. If you had one too many drinks the night before, this dish will cure that hangover. Hence the name Thai drunken noodles. 

Pad Thai - the typical and most popular stirred fried noodles in every Thai restaurant is passable and nothing extraordinary to report. The portion of Pad Thai is very generous in this restaurant. 

Chicken with green or red curry served with rice. The curry is served piping hot with onions, bamboo shoots, bell peppers and meat of your choice and came with a side of steamed jasmine rice. The curry broth is creamy and has a great coconut flavor and a nice spicy kick to it. 

I had also sampled other dishes that my coworkers ordered like Tom Yum Soup with shrimps, fish cakes appetizer, Penang Curry, and Thai crab fried rice. Overall, the food is not bad for lunch crowd. 

The also has a bar, which I suspect they do lots of business during happy hour or after business hours and being so close to the Moscone Center, they must get a lot of tourists. The restaurant has great acoustic so quiet enough that you can have a conversation without having to raise your voice even when the restaurant is packed. 

I will definitely come back to Cha-am not only because is walking distance from my office, but because they serve decent Thai dishes with affordable prices and the services is comparable.
author: Gourmet Princessa L.

description:
I've been sick the last few days so all I really wanted was some good soup. Luckily Cha-Am serves up a good silver noodle soup! I also tried the Tom Yum soup which was tasty too but I still prefer the silver noodle.

I also recommend the crab fried rice with real crab meat.
author: Helen Y.

description:
Soups are skippable, but salads are delicious. Sour, sweet, bitter, and spicy. Curries are watery and very mild, atleast for my taste. Noodle staples like Pad Se Ew, are tasty but average. Gai Yang is dry. Pad Ga Pow is delicious, but chicken is dry. 

Prices are pricey and portions are small. It probably doesn't help that the serving plates are enormous. Small portions on oversized plates, I just don't get it. Service is friendly, but a little jet lagged.

If you're near the MOMA, Yerba Buena Center or Moscone Center, seriously in pain for Thai food Cha-Am is a decent spot to fullfill your digestive needs. It's a far better choice compared to the neighborhood competitor, Osha Thai.

2 and a half stars.
author: Robin K.

description: The food is delicious, a little on the sweet side but the service is fast and friendly! Favorites are beef pad sew and fried tofu. Imperial rolls are very good as well!
author: Shiela D.

description: I live in the neighborhood and have several good (and even great) options for eating Thai. Cha-Am is solid Thai food and is especially good to order as carry out or to have delivered. It's also good value for your money compared to some of the others.
author: Neal C.

description: Expect to wait at least 20 minutes for your fried rice or pad see ew during lunch hour. Their food are quite expensive ($15 for duck fried rice? which costs $9 in Thai Noodles) and don't taste nearly as good as other Thai restaurants in the area.
author: Helen L.

description:
Sure, the decor is probably left over from when this place used to be a karaoke bar or disco but the food is wonderful. 

My favorite is their Pad See Ew with pork. The sauce is flavorful and coats each delicate noodle evenly with the perfect amount. The meat is always tender and plentiful. I only wish it came with more than 2 pieces of broccolli and slightly bigger portion sizes. I usually clean off my plate completely, and that's coming from someone who doesn't eat much.  

Most of the entrees I've tried here have been delicious and most range from $8-$10 each. Come early! It could get busy during lunch hour if there is a convention going on at the Moscone Center.
author: Vivian D.

description:
The decor is nice and our party was seated right away. We were trying to carb load prior to the SF Marathon and had visited Lulu's on Folsom, which was a disapointing waste btw..

Mission: To be fully fed before running SF Marathon
Accomplished? Food was good; BUT I KNOW there are some better places to stuff my face.
author: Laura K.

description:
And... like most places in the city, this place is going down. Their pad see ew used to be delicious. I used to dream about it! I would forgo my little WFH arrangement and take the 45 minute bus ride to work in the SOMA just to eat pad see ew for lunch.

- And lately, the dish has been white noodles with no sauce and almost no egg. 
- Pad Himalay Jay (Cashew nut tofu): Used to be extremely flavorful. With brown rice, it was a gastronomic delight. And now, I can't stand it. 

Sad.

What happened Cha Am? :(
author: Rahul A.

description:
After braving the SF Auto show with the wife and kindren, we decided to head to Pazzia to once again attempt to find decent Italian food.  While passing Cha-Am, which I had never noticed, I pulled it up on Yelp (mobile) to check the ratings, on the off chance that Pazzia was closed.

Sure enough, they were closed!  So, we backtracked to Cha-Am.

I asked for a Singha, but they were out.  OK, I said, what else do you have?  Phuket? (yes, it's pronounced the way you think it is).
"So sorry sir, ran out."  Sigh.

Having had excellent, almost spectacular Thai food in SF, I have to say I was disappointed.  The appetizers ranged from bland (Imperial rolls), greasy (chicken satay) and ok (pot stickers, a term I have never heard outside of SF, by the way).

Entrees were much better, both curry dishes with a good amount of flavor.  My girls had Pad Thai, which was a touch greasy and again, not spectatcularly flavorful.

If this were the first Thai place I had tried, having just arrived from NY, I would have rated it higher.  But knowing that there is so much better out there, I would not purposely venture back here.
author: dan s.

description:
Big place, mediocre food.  My pad thai noodle lunch was gummy, greasy, and made my guts feel yuckey for hours afterward.  

Avoid.
author: Tom S.

description:
What the hell happened to Cha-am? I thought it was great in the mid-90's. One of the top Thai places in the city. I've heard their Berkeley location has slid into mediocrity too. Went back recently and was not impressed at all. 

It was run-of-the-mill Thai. Raw mushrooms in the soup. Nothing special. Nothing popped. 

It probably deserves 3 stars, but I remember loving it so seeing it like this hurts all the more.

I guess it's kinda like I feel about the Slanted Door. It's a shame, but I guess their 15 minutes was like 10 years ago . . .
author: Andrew C.

description:
I've been to the Cha-Am location in Vallejo & was excited to hear that they had one in SF. 

My birthday fell on a Friday night. I was setting up a dinner & had 30 guests. You can just imagine the bajillion restaurants I called trying to make a reservation without having to have a set menu or putting down my credit card. I was going in between restaurants..& happened to call Cha-Am the night before (Thursday). They happily were able to accommodate for my last-minute dinner of 30 people on a Friday night. HELLOOO LIFE-SAVER! :)

My brother & his family went to eat at Cha-Am a couple hours before my reservation. He was surprised to see that they were already set up for my reservation. 

Dinner was great. We had great service. I enjoyed my Pad Se Ew. The owner even came to our table & greeted me a happy birthday :) 

There's also a full bar. The bartender was very entertaining & was a joy to have. I even got a free birthday doubleshot of Patron :) 

Parking is validated too :)
author: Jessica A.

description: I can't comment on the food, because the restaurant failed to honor my lunchtime reservation for five, despite the fact that our whole group showed up on time (12:45 PM).  They were woefully understaffed and pretended that I hadn't even made a reservation.
author: Raleigh M.

description: I've been to Cha-Am several times, because of it's proximity to my office.  I really like their chicken pad thai, and seafood dishes.  If you are looking for authentic Thai food, try somewhere else.  But if you want tasty Americanized Thai cuisine, I recommend checking this place out.
author: Jackson W.

description:
I think this place is ok.

Service - slow !! but they were nice 
Food - very tasty/ chicken was cooked too dry, but the sauces helped it somewhat/ very heavy on sauces/ vegetables cooked too soft for me 
Decor - cute 
Price- moderate/ they range from $7-10 

Note on the chicken satay appetizer: The chicken was cooked too dry and the portion size is small. It's not worth it.
author: Anna C.

description:
The owner, Toy, makes great food but sucks in liars dice. I came here last night because my friend Gene have been mentioning about this place for the longest time. Also, the bartender, Conson, was "supposedly" a very good liars dice player as well. I love the challenge. First thing that comes to mind when you mention Thai food.........Osha............Marnee..........King of Thai............ You have to give this place a shot because it is so different from the rest. 

You would never believe it but they have very good raw oysters here. You hear about Hog Island from the Ferry building, 1 dollar oysters from local restaurants in SOMA but you gotta check this place out. It is very under the radar and they are good!!!! 

The raw shrimp with garlic and chili (kinda like the Vietnamese style pork that you buy from the deli in the refrigerator section, I think it's called Nem) I have never had shrimp prepared this way before. It was fantastic. 

crab meat fried rice is amongst the best out there in the Thai restaurants. Very comparable to that of Osha Thai on Geary. 

The yellow curry with pork spareribs was very good. Fall off the bone good. Curry had just the right amount of heat and thickness. 

I honestly believe their rib eye steak here is probably better than most steak houses in the City. Very tender, juicy, cooked to perfection. I was actually blown away with this dish. A Thai restaurant that serves great steaks???? 

Back to the liars dice game with the bartender...............hence the 4 star and not a 5. hahhaahha. I will come back again because the people here really value your business. You ever been to a mom and pop and they honestly care about you? This place is like that, a very family oriented place that serves up one of the best Thai food in the City. A very hidden gem if you were to ask me.
author: jason g.

description:
My new go to place for delivery Thai food. 

Veg drunken noodle and mango sticky rice I heart thee. 

Promise not to make me gain weight and we will remain friends.
author: Amber F.

description:
So-so Thai food.  There are plenty of Thai options in SOMA, so you might as well skip this one.  Their Tom Yum soup was a huge disappointment.

Also a little on the pricey side for what it is.
author: Alison M.

description:
A friend of mine and I came to dine here after attending a convention at the Moscone center. It was late, we were tired, this restaurant was conveniently located directly adjacent to the Moscone center and we both generally love Thai so we figured, what could go wrong? Famous last words...

I easily had the most awkward service I've ever had in my life at this restaurant. We sat down and immediately ordered drinks and appetizers to buy ourselves some time to decide on the entrée. Our waitress took our orders, but when we asked to hold on to a menu while we deliberate on the main course, she told us she had to take our menus to take our orders. Why do you have to take our menus? What reason could you possibly have? We just wound up ordering the our appetizers (again) later with our entrée.

The appetizers we ordered were soft shell crab tempura and prawn satay. The soft shell crab tempura was pretty good, but frankly its very difficult to get deep fried crab wrong. The prawn satay on the other hand, was very bizarre. I expected prawns on skewers and covered in satay sauce, but instead we received prawns caked in a flat, rectangular fishcake patty on skewers and covered in sauce. What was up with the fishcake patty? Not only would prawns on a stick have been perfectly acceptable, but the fish cake also had the texture and elasticity of rubber, which was pretty gross.

I also had the tom yum goong, which was tasty, but not nearly spicy enough. The soup was by no means bad, and its just barely nudging me over from giving this place a one star rating, but it was disappointing. Meanwhile my friend ordered a curry dish that was way too dry. She couldn't finish it, but it wasn't even worth packing up to take home. 

I would not come to this restaurant again. The food was weird and unexpected in a bad way, the service was awkward, and it was even somewhat expensive. Walk down the street to Osha or even walk a little further to Ozone and you'll have a much better time.
author: Tian X.

description:
Nice little joint with a broad menu, including a full line of Daily Specials. Had a late lunch, so can't judge the crowds. It's close to Moscone Center South, so if you're in town for a conference, it's a nice escape.

My massaman curry with prawns was very nice. The person I lunched with had drunken chicken that he said was very good, as well.
author: Steve S.

description: That's the real Thai food. Loved the Sea Love and the Green Curry Chicken plus the young coconut :)
author: Amy L.

description: I went to Cha-Am with some friends who were visiting from out of town. The ambience was pleasant could even be used for a romantic dinner. The night we went they must have been short staffed in the kitchen because service was very slow. I wish they told us about the delay but that being said the food was very good. We ordered the green mango salad with shrimp which was amazing best mango salad I've ever had! Definitely made up for the 40 min delay. The rest of our meal was good we ordered our usual thai order which was green curry, red curry and a fried rice. We all enjoyed our selves only downfall was how long the food took to come out.
author: Sandhya R.

description:
I went here last night for a friends birthday party. I had the yellow chicken curry with rice and also tried their thai beer, Singha.

I feel that this place is a lot fancier than say.... King of Thai. If you're looking for a nice place to gather with your friends, hang out, talk and eat some decent thai food- then this is the place to go! But if you're looking for something quick then i think you can go else where for something better.

The food itself was OK, but the presentation was really nice and i liked how the tables were set and the atmosphere of the place.

Curry- 
it was a bit watery. I like my curry think so that it mixes with my rice just the way i like it. But because it wasn't as thick as i expected, it just sank to the bottom of my bowl through my rice :( ... that was a downer for sure. 

My friends got the Pad Thai -- it looked a little dry.. 

Calamari- on the CHEWIER part w/excessive breading.. but the asian/thai dipping sauce was pretty freakin awesome ;p  P.S. the breading got soggy towards the end..  (NO BUENO!)

Bartender! I met his yesterday and he was super friendly. Definitely hooked it up with some awesome Patron shots-- but maybe he was just being EXTRA friendly because we were pretty freakin awesome:) !!!!
author: Hanna K.

description:
I used to eat at Cha-Am until Osha, CLG, Ozone Thai, etc opened up, only because it was the only Thai restaurant close to where I live (without ordering delivery). I now get my thai food from Osha (on 3rd street). It is the best tasting thai restaurant around the area and is decently priced for the quality and quantity.

But Osha only has one vegetarian dish that contains mostly miushrooms and it is the only disappointing vegetarian dish I have eaten there. So the other night when I was craving thai food and mushrooms, I found myself ordering takeout from Cha-Am. Among my order were the following dishes ...

PAD-HED-RUAM-MIT
Sautéed fresh mushrooms, shitake mushrooms, oyster mushrooms, and deep-fried tofu, with garlic and Thai herb sauce, yellow onions, green onions, and vegetables. 

GAENG-DANG-HED 
Spicy red curry of mushrooms (fresh straw mushrooms, black mushrooms and oyster mushrooms) with coconut milk, Thai herbs, sweet basil, and bell pepper

I placed my order LATE. There were only patrons at the bar and only one other couple ordering takeout. My food took FOREVER!!!! And there was not one single mushroom in my red curry. I also asked for my dishes to NOT contain any tofu ... and TWO of my dishes had TOFU. Really? 

I guess there were other reasons I stopped going to Cha-Am that I forgot about. Their effort on service was quite pathetic. I have learned my lesson ( hopefully I won't forget again!).
author: Ginger K.

description:
With Thai restaurants, I usually care about two things: food and decor. And unfortunately, Cha-Am was not good with either. 

I ordered the Pad See Ew - my usual at Thai restaurants. The food was greasy, greasy, greasy. So greasy it made me feel slightly sick eating it. In addition, there was this patch near the center of my plate that was sour. YUCK. This was especially scary for me because my number one fear is eating rotten/ moldy food. Needless to say, I did not finish my meal. 

As for the service, I ordered to go because I had to rush back to work (or face the wrath of my boss). And it took over 40 minutes for my food to come and another 15 minutes for the bill to get taken care of. The restaurant was not full, unless you count the crowded bar, who hadn't, as far as I could tell, ordered anything except beer.  

Just to be fair, I took my order to go, so maybe that had something to do with the quality of my food. In any case, I will not be going back.
author: Jessica R.

description: Ok, lets be honest.  From the outside, this place has no appeal.  That's what I thought walking by the restaurant for over 2 years since it's in my neighborhood.  I finally tried it when a neighbor told me that it's her "to-go" place for home style Thai cooking.  So I took the plunge and much to my surprise, the food is pretty good!  I appreciate that the food is less oily than Osha Thai.  I like Osha and it's got a cool vibe but foodwise, Cha-am is better (and in my mind, less expensive).  I am now a regular customer and am glad I took the plunge!
author: C T.

description:
I just got take out today from Cha Am, so can't comment on the service (or, sadly, on dessert for that matter).

But the red curry dish I ordered for lunch was *delicious*!  Moderately spicy and perfectly creamy curry with a nicely proportioned mix of vegetables, basil, and chicken.  Both the curry and the rice that came with it were generously portioned.

The decor and atmosphere?  I'd say relaxing / comforting.  Certainly not authentic Thai, nor ostentatious.  Just pleasant.

And from what I've read from the reviews, curries are what's especially good at Cha Am, so I hope to stop back, try a different curry... and some dessert!

(side note:  you should have seen the envious / pissed looks on peoples' faces when I walked back with my curry to the conference I'm attending, while they were suffering through the all-too-common gross sandwich box).
author: Adam L.

description:
Pad ke mow me!

This is my go to Thai place by my work. I take new hires and people I am meeting with here when Osha Thai is too loud or crowded. They are all so nice, and I think they are actually all thai, which makes it feel more authentic.
 My favorite thai dish is this saucy thick noodle dish called pad kee mow, and even though its not on the list, they always make it for me. The chili condiments that they bring you when you ask for hot sauce are AMAZING! I like things spicy, so the dry chili mix they have is always a must for me. pad kra pao is a must try here as well, I always ask for extra sauce and veggies!

The only thing that keeps me awake after a lunch here is there thai coffees, which are bomb!
author: Marlene D.

description: I started eating at this place 18 years ago in Berkeley and it still ROCKS!  I order for delivery all the time and I eat in only sometimes.  The food is pretty great!
author: Eileen L.

description:
We've been to this place maybe about 4 - 5 times for dinner and have always been 100% satisfied. Excellent vegetarian / vegan selection and if you ask for spicy the spicy tray that they bring you is incredible!

What really makes this place so outstanding is their fresh tofu soup. It's coconut based with the best lime / maybe lemongrass and I don't know what they do to this soup but it is so nourishing, satisfying and the best way to start a meal.

I also really love their curry specials that have pumpkin. If you see red curry and pumpkin - buy that.

Anyway, the soup is craveable, the staff is super nice and this is one of my favorite Thai places in SF.
author: Allegra F.

description: The food is DELICIOUS always. During peak times, the restaurant is totally packed with people and service is very slow. Outside of peak times, it is very good. The noodle dishes (especially pad kee mao) are very delicious and spicy! Good vegetarian/vegan and gluten-free options.
author: Neesha S.

description:
Like other reviewers, I too roll my eyes at the fact that Osha has landed across the street. Common now...really? Luckily I think the service at Cha-Am is sweet, the food is good, and they have a really reasonably priced lunch menu that should make it so they'll be able to hold their own...I think...I hope. I'll be sad if I come back to Cali and they've closed. 

I got a chicken dish with baby corn, the name of which I can't remember, though let's call it Ga Baby Corn. Is "Ga" chicken? It was super tasty. The vegetables were fresh and crisp, the chicken was flavored nicely, and they added a bit of spice upon request. My soup on the other hand...not so great, but I'll glaze over that because the entree, the service, the friendly staff more than made up for a bum bowl.

Know Before You Go: You've probably already been to Osha, give these guys a try. The interior isn't spectacular, but you're there to eat.
author: Corey D.

description:
I was introduced to and fell in love with Thai food by the sister Cha-Am in Berkeley.  I have tried other Thai restaurants but had been disappointed that they don't compare.  So my review will be a compare and contrast with the other Cha-Am.  I have passed by this Cha-Am in the city many times and have been meaning to try it out.  Needless to say, my bf took me to celebrate my birthday and I was blown away.

The decor is more french modern than Thai/Asian.  We went on a Weds. night and it wasn't busy.  The service was very good.  The food came in a timely manner and the wait staff were attentive.  We ordered 3 dishes and Thai ice tea and green tea for drinks.  The Pad-Thai and Mu-Yang are priced similar to the other Cha-Am.  The curry dish was quite a bit larger (almost double),  so the higher price was well worth it.

I love the grilled pork or Mu-Yang at the Berkley Cha-Am.  This was a little different.  They had 2 thick pork chops with a salad instead of grilled thin slices of pork.  It was OK but of course it's all about the yummy dipping sauce.  I don't know what the other restaurant puts in its sauce, but it's heavenly sweet.  This was close but not quite it.

We also tried the veggie Pad-Thai.  It was really good.  Everything was served on the plate separately, so you have to kind of toss it to mix the ingredients together.  The veggies (string beans, carrots, and squash) were fresh and cooked perfectly.  This was the first time trying a vegetarian Pad Thai but I liked it a lot, nice and fresh with the pea-nutty taste you love.  I usually order a chicken or prawn Pad Thai.

Last, we had the green curry chicken or Gaeng-Keo-Wan.  This was deelish.  When I think of Thai curries, I think of a sweet spicy.  It is definitely more spicy than the Berkeley restaurant.  I loved this dish but then I like spicy things.  The bf wasn't as happy asking for more water.  The only thing that could improve it would be to thicken the sauce more with maybe some more coconut milk. YUM...
author: Judy K.

description:
Decently sized portions and reasonable prices for the area.  Nice decor - very modern.  However, service wasn't that great.  The staff was not friendly whatsoever and just really seemed unhappy to be there.  I guess I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and say it was just one of those off days....I guess!  

Nonetheless, the food was pretty tasty for the most part.  The fried shrimp cakes were really good.  Chicken with green curry - just oook.  Veggie pad see ew was my favorite by far - super tasty.  Lastly, the grilled pork chop was way too tough and was our least favorite dish.

Overall though, not bad.  They're in a prime location too, so I'm sure they get a decent amount of foot traffic from those who are craving for Thai food, but don't want Osha's right across the street.
author: Carmen Y.

description:
Our Museum Parc HOA party was catered by ChaAm. The reviews were 5 Star. We had yummy platters of Chicken Satay, Shrimp Satay, vegetarian Spring Rolls, Pot stickers and fried Tofu. Everything was fresh, hot and delicious with a variety of sauces for dipping. Perfect for our event. Gary  was great to work with since we had some special requests and a limited budget. They even delivered.  I highly recommend ChaAm for dinner or for events.

Jane H
author: Jane H.

description:
Used to eat at the one in Berkeley all the time.  Went to this one recently for a work lunch.    

Pubic hair in the rice.  End of story.
author: Harold B.

description: Been twice for lunch, watered down curry,  slow service, bland soups compared to other Thai restaurants in the area.
author: J H.

description:
Since I live right across the street, it's my default place for take-out on a lazy weekday when I'm feeling Thai food. The food is good. Their Pad-See-Ew (is that how you spell it?!) is one of the better ones I've had. 
More importantly, the ambiance here is better than the average Thai restaurant. The place is spacious with cute decors and the music in the background is relaxing...again unlike most Thai restaurants. 

The restaurant also has a full bar - I'm surprised people don't come here more often! It's great and I recommend it.
author: Nattie X.

description: This restaurant offers tasty food in a nice atmosphere and is conveniently located near both my office - which I'll admit, probably doesn't help YOU any - and within easy walking distance of the Montgomery BART station. I went again recently with co-workers on a blustery day, and we found the hot, spicy food comforting. Soup is a particularly economical deal if you're in that kind of mood. Enjoy!
author: Bill B.

description:
I came here with my bf late night for dinner on Valentine's Day.  We really wanted Osha at the Embarcadero, but because of the Annual Pillow fight that night, it was crowded and the wait was super long.  We heard that they opened a new Osha on 2nd or 3rd and Folsom (we've been to the one on Mission several times before) so we drove over.  I didn't like how they opened right across the street from another Thai Food restaurant.  Me being a supporter of the small business (at least smaller than the Osha chain), I opted for Cha-am instead and plus we had just ran 8 miles and didn't feel like showering or changing (TMI) and I didn't think our outfits would be appropriate in there.

Anyway, we ordered a beef and fish dish with 3 bowls of rice.  The servers were very attentive and so friendly.  The food was very flavorful.  Prices are about the same as Osha.

Minus one star because they accidentally included grautity in my check.  I didn't find out until after I added more tip and thought to myself, "wow, this is expensive".  anyway, they were genuinely apologetic and offered to remove it.  

I would come here again.  Support the small business!
author: Erika C.

description: Decent Thai food, but nothing spectacular.  Tried the papaya salad and red chicken curry.  The food came out pretty quickly.  The papaya salad was fine, but not as tangy as I like.  The curry was good, but the rice was a bit lumpy.  Okay and not too expensive.
author: Michelle C.

description:
My favorite.

Affordable. Tasty. Fast. 

The Pad See Ew is delicious. Everything else I've gotten there has been fabulous. Tastes like it does in Thailand.
author: Simone B.

description:
Pretty decent Thai food.  The tamarind duck was pretty tasty, but there was barely any duck in the dish itself, which disappointed me.  The pad thai was good, but pretty standard.

Nice quiet atmosphere with some good service.  The prices were also pretty standard.
author: Gene A.

description:
WARNING: When you mix one part green pork curry, one part yellow tofu curry, one part chicken satay, one part......

...okay, okay, lets just say that the 6 other things my friends and I ordered for take out were equally delicious.....

anyhow, when you mix them with 3 parts good red wine and one part Office Space you will enter a food coma. 

You will wake up dazed and confused at 4am on your friends couch, sneak out quietly, find a street cleaning ticket on your car because you passed the acceptable time to park due to said food coma. 

As a result your dinner will have cost you $50 instead of the standard $10 your 5 other friends chipped in for 9, yes 9, menu items. 

You will not care because the food was fantastic, as was the company, and the couch was a comfortable place to fall into a coma (thanks Jason). Besides, if need be, you wont have to pay that ticket until its time to register your car anyhow!
author: Drue C.

description:
Feeling hungry, we left the opening party at YBCA in search of some food. Thai came to mind, so we walked over to Osha on 2nd St. It was after 8pm and people were spilling out of the doors like it was noon during the work week. I maneuvered through the crowd and went up to the hostess who told me that the wait would be 30 minutes for a table for four. Too hungry to wait that long.

Then I remembered about Cha-Am. I hadn't been there since Osha opened across the street from my office. So, I took my friends on a walkabout and ended up a block away from where we had started. We had built up even more of an appetite and I was just hoping that there wouldn't be a wait there. Luckily, there wasn't. There were plenty of empty tables and the staff in bright Hawaiian shirts were happy to seat us. I thought, poor Cha-Am, Osha has taken away all of your business. 

The food had always been good before, and this time didn't disappoint. The yellow curry chicken, beef short ribs, pad thai, and rainbow salad were all flavorful and tasty. We ended our meal with an order of fried bananas with coconut ice cream - make sure you save room for this! For all of this, it only came out to $12 per person. 

The service was fast, the atmosphere casual and great for dining with friends, and apparently "the spot" for locals to slam some shots at the bar. 

So if you're looking for some good Thai food, Cha-Am is a great alternative to Osha. You won't feel pressured to hurry up and finish your meal so the people waiting at the door can take your table, and the servers make sure you're having a good meal and a good time.
author: Connie C.

description: The food here is consistently fresh and delicious, and the service is always super friendly.  I am a fan of Cha-Am.  :)
author: Tasha D.

description:
Every officer worker's got to have a next-door Thai place, right?  Mine is Grand Pu Bah, and the wife's is now Cha-Am (not to be confused with Cha-at, the Indian place around the corner).

Like GPB, Cha-am is no dive; in fact it's decked out enough to be a classy spot for dinner (complete with a full bar and that deco-ish circular parapet).  Yet at lunch you can get a broad selection of items for a mere $7.50 (including a veggie dish made with gluten cakes--reminded me of the gooey rice globs you can get at Korean places).  In the end, though, GPB wins out as my favorite--yes, it's much trendier, and pricier, but they also put that extra oomph into the food, which is definitely lacking in Cha-Am's by-the-numbers curries.  Still, for a cheap, everyday office lunch, you could do worse.
author: Wes M.

description:
It's a good alternative to the usual YBG/Metreon fare, and very reasonably priced. For $46. all four of us had a delightful dinner of:

Rainbow Salad (very fresh, sour and spicy hot, but lacking the complexity of the 14-ingredient fave found elsewhere)
Yellow Curry Chicken - typically good
Beef Short Ribs - very tasty, a little fatty in a good way
Fried Bananas with Coconut Ice Cream - delicious

Dinner is only as good as your company. Our company was warm, witty and entertaining...and we were welcome to hang out and entertain one another well after dinner was over.

No, I'm not naming names, but you know who you are.
author: Andy R.

description: Got the $17 grilled seafood special, $1 for hot tea  --  no soup, no salad, no rice, no service.  No return visit.
author: Jaime O.

description: Unfortunately, quiet dining spots are few and far between, but the silence here is oddly unsettling, possibly because the space is so huge. The menu is comprised of traditional Thai dishes, with most items priced at less than $10. A very spicy hot-and-sour soup with prawns, lemongrass, and fresh mushrooms will bring an instant sweat to your brow. Curry selections are very good, but the grilled options I've tried were overcooked and dry. Convenient to MoMa, or if you're going to a film at the Metreon, it's a decent alternative to the food court there.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
Went here last weekend with some girlfriends on accident... we tried to try 2 other thai places, but both were closed. I guess places in the area don't find it important to stay open on Sundays! But luckily, Cha-Am saved the day. 

We first shared the papaya salad, which was really yummy! We ordered it sans shrimp, substituting tofu, and they first brought it out with shrimp. They were quick to correct it, but it still tasted slightly like seafood to me. Regardless, it was spicy , crunchy, and delicious!

I had the red curry, which was really great, spicy, and a great value!! It comes with rice, and was more food than I could finish in a sitting. I think I need to stop eating out for dinner and convert to eating out for lunch, because lunch specials are awesome!! 

Overall, I think we were all pretty satisfied, though our noses were running by the end from the spiciness of the dishes. But, I love spicy, so I can't complain! They did fumble the splitting of the bill (equally!) onto 3 credit cards... they charged 2 of us correctly, but charged the other of us the price of the full bill--whoops! We caught it and it was corrected quickly. Despite the couple missteps by this place, I liked it. 4 stars!
author: Bridgette A.

description:
One of the few places in San Francisco that feels like it could be anywhere in America. Food and service were both good, but unremarkable. The highlight was a daily special appetizer: a fresh spring roll with duck. 

The space is huge, with a healthy dose of neon and crazy casino carpet that all makes you feel like you're in some early 90s movie. Perhaps it's the proximity to the Moscone Center that gives it that anonymous convention feel. Who knows. But, as a non-tourist with a bit of knowledge about the City, I certainly wouldn't go out of my way to stop by Cha-Am (even with the free 2-hour weekday parking at Museum Parc Garage).
author: Erin M.

description: Love this place, the food is surprisingly very, very good. It's pretty fast, good service, and great food. Definitely better than the Osha across the street (and cheaper). My favorite dish is the Gai-Yang grilled chicken, it's phenomenal. Their salads are also really good. I've been coming here for a little over a year, and I'll keep coming here while I live in sf!
author: Caro C.

description:
I like Thai food...a lot.  Actually, strike that...I LOVE Thai food, am obsessed with it, stalk it every chance I get and would honestly rub myself all over with coconut milk and pad thai, if given the chance.

Cha-am is conveniently located a mere block away from my work.  I came here for lunch with two of my favorite co-workers.  Not only was the company divine, but the food....oh, the food did not disappoint.  The imperial rolls were crispy, fresh and flavorful; my chicken dish (the name escapes me) was cooked to perfection and left me feeling slightly giddy, not to mention very very full.  

Will definitely return.
author: Daniela L.

description:
My new go-to place for takeout.  I ordered from work, walked there in ten minutes and picked up a very satisfying dinner. (I was starving, and it was perfect).  The manager was very friendly in taking my order and very friendly when handing over my bag of food. 

I ordered the green curry with chicken (abundant with vegetables- so good and so spicy I was crying), chicken pad thai (tangier than what I normally am used to- but I liked it. And again, tons of sprouts an add-ins- I love that!) and lastly, papaya salad which was very spicy and very fresh- plus they have fresh prawns in the salad (instead of the dried shrimp that usually comes in papaya salad)..as well as tons of greens.  I'm a big fan.  Only disappointing thing was the serving of rice was too small- I'll order a larger size next time.

Ambiance of the place was a bit gloomy, so I'll probably stick to takeout or an I'm too-tired-to-cook-or-exercise-so-let's-just-walk-there-and-pretend-that-counts-as-a -workout type of night.
author: Sonia S.

description: The service was awful. It took over 30 min to get any food. We never got our appetizer. I had to re order my tea. Their special dish was was over priced and poorly prepared.
author: J L.

description:
This place is like the more sophisticated twin sister of the Berkeley Cha-am. It's only Thai themed in its art and pottery, uses regular glasses instead of the pretty metal drinking bowls, has a full bar and doesn't feel like you're sitting in a Thai shack. However, the food is still very very good, the prices are great (especially for lunch) and is my favorite Thai restaurant in SF.

The curries seem slightly hotter than in Berkeley and use more vegetables, which I really like. The pork imperial rolls with the spicy sweet sauce are heavenly and the Thai iced tea is top notch, just as in Berkeley. The only thing that disappoints me about this Cha-am is that the grilled pork (mu yang) is a bone-in pork chop instead of thin flash grilled pieces - harder to eat and not as flavorful.
author: Kristina A.

description:
Waited 45 minutes for lunch that never came, during a semi-busy lunch hour where the restaurant was only 1/2 full. Saw everyone else eat their food and leave, asked the server twice for an update and heard nothing/nada/zip. 

No thanks.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
A few co-workers and I have lunch at Cha Am at least once a week.  I've tried a few items on their lunch menu but lately I've been ordering the same dish.  What can I say?  I'm a creature of habit.

Anyway, the staff is friendly and sweet.  They recognize me and know what I want before I even sit down.  Good food, decent service (it can get a little hectic during the lunch rush), pretty clean, good location.
author: Conny W.

description:
I've been going to this place for more than 5 years now (I've lost count) for weekday lunches.  First, I have to say I love Thai food, so maybe I'm a little biased.  However, I have been to Thai places that I thought were pitiful.  This is not one of them.

I agree with one of the previous posts.  Their pad see ew is one of the best around!!  That's my go-to dish.  I've tried a couple of their daily special dishes too - usually vegetable/chicken/basil/chili - very tasty too.

I would advise against the Thai iced tea.  I'm usually a big fan of Thai iced tea.  But here, they make it WAY too sweet.  This coming from someone with a sweet tooth.  I also wouldn't go for their crab fried rice - tasty, but they're not so good about getting all the shell out!

Their service has been excellent...that is, nice & efficient. 5 years ago, I wouldn't have said the same thing.  They used to have problems getting the food out all at the same time to a party of more than 3 or 4.  Your friends on both sides of you would get their dishes, and 10 minutes later, you'd still be sitting there salivating.  But now - no problems!!  I also like the comfortable ambiance of this place.  It feels almost like you're eating at someone's house - ALMOST.  At least you don't have to yell to hear the person across the table from you, like you do at another nearby Thai restaurant.  I recommend this place for a dependably solid Thai meal, good service, reasonable prices.
author: A Y.

description:
Being the Thai-aficionado that I am, I can't help but come here for lunch at least once during the work week. The Gao-Pao Tofu is one of my favorites - so flavorful and delish that you wouldn't even think to remember that it belongs on the vegetarian list. Despite the mismatched decor and Hawaiian shirt wearing staff, it's one of the better and more affordable Thai restaurants in SOMA. 

But I do have one burning question left to be answered...

Tom Yum Soup, 
Why must you taste so good yet hurt me so bad with your MSG?
author: Joyce L.

description: I forgot about this place till I went there tonight. The food is consistantly good and it's a good sign that they are still in business because most of the places on 3rd St went out of business. I ordered duck entree tonight and it was so good that I finished the whole thing!
author: Yoko S.

description:
Been here a few times for lunch. Good tasty Thai food. Like the Today's Specials on a big board that is given to each table. We had the green curry giant prawn and Pad Ga Pao and both were very good and spicy.

This place can get busy during lunch time so you should get there before noon. Prices are very reasonable especially it's table-clothed. Two people for like 23 bucks you can't really beat that!
author: T L.

description:
Went here for a late-night dinner after Pazzia was fully booked.  I had not been here in a long time, but of my companions had been.  The place was virtually empty at 9p, so we got a nice window table.
Our waitress put us off immediately with her cold manner as if she wasn't glad to see late customers.  But our food server was extremely friendly and polite so that made up for it.
We had the soft-shelled crab as an appetizer and that was quite good although a tad oily.
For entrees, two of us had the grilled seafood plate which was very well done while I had a Kao-Pad with chicken.  There were lots of vegetables with the fried rice which I enjoyed, but the dish was lukewarm.
Our server was prompt and efficient so all in all we were satisfied with the meal.
author: Philip C.

description:
let me tell you, i never order pad thai when i go out to thai restaurants, but i had a hankering for some the other day and this restaurant is just around the corner from where we live. a great find! 

although i have to say that this restaurants need a whole new decor, a new concept. they're stuck in the 80's it feels like. i bet they'd get more business if they did remodel though. but still nice, white table cloth and everything. and the have a fully stocked bar. 

the pad thai was really good, but i was sad that it came with 5 "prawns" instead of 6 like it said they would. and when i think prawns, i think somewhat larger shrimp, these were dinky. but no more complaining. 
bf got yellow curry with chicken, good too. and another beef dish that we had to take home since we were so full. 

we both ordered dessert, him the fried banana & mango ice cream. me, the mango and sticky rice. again, good, but a little disappointed at the portion size. there was only one small piece of mango and the sticky rice just wasn't...sticky enough. it didn't have that same coconut'y/salty taste to it. 

all in all, decent meal for good price.
author: Anh P.

description: The crab fried rice was flavorful with real crab meat alongside many other dishes such as the rainbow salad, green curry chicken that were tasty. The Rib-yang that night was a lil on the fatty side but still very delicious. Mango sticky rice and fried banana ice-cream sealed the deal.
author: Yan M.

description: Avoid the soft shell tempura. It has no business being on the menu. The flank steak lacked a little in its presentation but tasted great. The mango and sticky rice was as always great.
author: Bob J.

description: Andrew C. turned me on to this place and it will always be one of my favorite lunch spots. The inside decor looks like a mix of '80's with art deco and Asian inspiration...It actually looks like a night club in there. I love it! The price is right (under $10) and so so so so good. I order the prawns with eggplant or the spicy tofu! Yum.
author: Rachel W.

description:
This is another "Thai" joint.

Its good, nothing specular, but consistent.  No misses, just no real hits either.

The atmosphere is forgettable, but the staff is pleasant.

Best choice, lunch.
author: Ken p.

description:
A good decent, quick lunch. 

I came here on a business lunch and had some chicken with tofu. The dish was pretty solid. Though, being an avid rice eater, I've had better. Seemed like it was sitting out for a while. You'd think they'd have fresh rich for the busy lunch hour. 

Service was just alright. They were on top of their game on refilling drinks. But, that was it. If anything else was needed, it was hard to get someone's attention. 

Ambiance is nice and cute, not too loud or crowded. I'd come back.
author: Jon C.

description: I've never really indulged in thai food but i had to today. I ordered the Yang kui (or yang cho i forget the proper name) chicken. it comes with brown rice a salad and 2 chicken breasts marinated in these finger licking sauce. i wanted to drink the sauce they had. not to mention it came with a little sweet and sour sauce. the server was nice and the prices was cheap. i highly recommend this place
author: Tareau B.

description:
This place is across the street from my office so it's definitely convenient.  The decor is a bit kitchy Asian restaurant, but sort of on the verge of being a dump.

The food ranges from pretty tasty to average.  The curries are definitely their strong suit and the noodle dishes are often hit or miss.  I will say that the portions are quite large, particularly if you do take out.

The few bad experiences I have had was with service, even when I go to pick up.  Once I showed up to pick up my order (and I definitely wasn't early).  I think at that time they basically started my order because they made me waiting for almost 15 minutes.  And it seems that every time they take your cash at the front, it takes them forever to make change.

If it wasn't the fact that they are across from my office, I probably wouldn't go.
author: Philip D.

description:
I went with a friend at like 9:30 at night on a sunday so I was expecting a few more people in the resturant since most things are closed at that time in the area, but no one else was even there. It kinda frightened me, but the atmosphere looked alright. My friend Courtney and I tried an appetizer of the spicy calamari, which was alright, nothing special. She ordered the pad thai and she enjoyed it, but i doubt she was wildly impressed, and I had the BBQ chicken thingy... it was ok. It was REALLY fatty, like peices of fat on the chicken, which grosses me out a little, but a lot of people want that.. whatev.

The service was good though, although we were the only ones in the resturant and their were 5 people working there. Our water was always filled, until we paid where we were completely forgotten. It was oddly silent all the time in there, almost enough to make it where i wanted to not talk to my friend at times cause i felt the servers were listening on. Anyways, 3 out of 5 because they tried and were not bad, just not that good. It was alright... yah.

-Spicy Calamari (Alright)
-Pad Thai (Tiny Bit Greasy)
-BBQ Chicken (Ehh, had much better at other Thai places)
author: Preston B.

description:
Service is always pleasant and deserves a solid 4 stars, Food is more like a 3.5 maybe more.... 

I've ordered:

Pad Thai- eh... I've had better
Shrimp Cakes- Me no likee! Veggies are not diced small enough for the cakes so sometimes you get a big chunk of onion or whatever
Pad See Ew- Jackpot!!! I've decided to stick with this dish since it's cooked perfectly everytime. I go here at least once a week (like today I'm going for lunch) and you can bet your ass I'm ordering the Pad See Ew.

However, I will eventually take the suggestions of a few Yelpers and try the Papaya Salad.
author: Eclectic C.

description: Be sure to order rice if you order a curry.  Unlike most Thai restaurants they don't give you rice automatically.
author: Ron S.

description:
Decent enough Thai, on a hurry. I've gone for a lunch a couple of times, but also for dinner. The staff are non-fussy, and the food comes out pretty quickly. 

It's a casual spot, nothing fancy, easy to get a table, in and out fast.

Was here on a Friday night most recently, after a party at YBCA. Not much of a spillover crowd but there were some ruffians drinking at the bar, I mean really getting loaded, and for some reason this added to the atmosphere. I mean, who comes to Cha-Am to do shots?
author: Nish N.

description: Probably the blandest pad thai I've ever had. All the food was delivered luke warm or cold. Pricey, too. Skip!
author: Brian D.

description:
There is something unholy going on with Thai food in San Fran.  It could just be me, but it seems like San Fran is awash in mediocre Thai restaurants.  It's raining average Thai restaurants.  It's like some sort of plague destroying the city from the inside out. 

I kind of yearn for a Chan Dara -- something not dumpy that serves wonderful food at reasonable prices.  90% of the Thai restaurants in this city look like they were decorated when Captain and Tennille ruled the airwaves.  This place is, sadly, no exception.
author: Tim G.

description:
This place has really good yellow curry and papaya salad like I haven't had in a while.  I LOVE the smelly papaya salad that has the shrimp paste and the fishy smell.  LOVE IT.  Does not taste the same without it, and they make it that way.

The service is OK if you go there when it's slow.  When you go at busier times they don't seem to be organized enough to handle the rush.  

Another thing is, they put giant pieces of paper on top of the tables for easy clean up.  BEWARE!  Paper-cut zone.  Whenever I leave this place I have at least 2 paper cuts on my hands.  I'm not sure the service is good enough that it's worth getting a staph infection.  Probably best to take it to go.  I would really stay if they just used glass tops and windex.
author: Wilson K.

description:
Delicious!!  I discovered this spot while in town for a conference, and it was absolutely perfect for lunch!  Fortunately, I came in a little early, for this place filled up FAST!  By the time I left, there was a line out the door!

I had some Tom-Ka-J, which was absolutely awesome, followed by the spicy tofu, which was delicious!  Having food like this made me miss living in SF.  :(  Now, I know of a terrific spot next time I am back!

The service at lunch can be a little slow, due to the massive amount of people dining here, so just a heads up to bring your patience hat!
author: Lynn L.

description: Not bad at all. Perfectly good choice if you find yourself looking for Thai in SOMA, but I wouldn't drive into town just to eat her...
author: Brian L.

description:
Special #6 today - Pineapple chicken - 9.75

Heavy on sauces, and chicken was dry. 

I've had better, with a lot less sauce.
author: Angela C.

description: Oddly not as good as the Berkeley location, but when I need a break from Osha, I come to Cha Am.
author: Jen D.

description: Great Thai food. Everthing here is wonderful. The only thing I hate are their bathrooms. Why is it so freakin hot back there???
author: Lisa R.

description:
I kept walking past this place and wondered why it wasn't busy compared to Osha across the street. Looking at the specials menu posted in the window, "Crab fried rice" I was sold. 

The service was welcoming and attentive. 

The prices were a lot lower but did not lack in the quality or taste.
Items ordered were, crab fried rice, beef short ribs, pad see ew and roasted duck rolls. All were fantastic except for the duck rolls. Too sticky and lacked duck. The sauces were delicious that accompanied all our dishes and the thai iced tea was only 1.50!! I highy recommend you give this place a try.
author: kelly y.

description:
The food here is pretty food for the price!  Its fresh and priced decently.  

There are three issues I have with this place:
1) After eating here once a week for a couple months they not once made the food per my special requests. I LOVE SPICY FOOD and not once did they even attempt to make it spicy.  My last time I even asked for "Thai spicy" which in other restaurants has gotten me in trouble...good trouble!

2) Wait staff is not bad but not good. It takes 10-15 minutes from finishing my food to getting the bill, paying and getting my change back. And that is when its not busy and a majority of the wait staff is just hanging out folding silverware and chatting it up.

3) The music.  I hate smooth jazz with a passion.  Its almost as bad and as annoying as the awful techno in Sushi Club.

Id like to give extra stars for the food but just cant cuz of the above.
author: Bigfrog W.

description:
I've been here a couple of times and never been disappointed. I've never really been wowed either, but I've always left satisfied. I've sampled quite a few menu items and the only bad thing I can say is that once I ordered a dish that came with some pretty funky looking broccoli with black spots all over it. I should have said something, but I'm a bit shy about sending things back. Anyway, it tasted alright, although I avoided the especially funky looking pieces.

Cha Am serves solid, if unexceptional, Thai food at reasonable prices in a nice setting with a full bar. Good value and fine quality, but nothing to really knock your socks off.
author: Brian H.

description:
Setting:  Very nice, not so showy setting.  The bar is a nice addition for just to hang out.  Big windows to people watch thru, although the only view you'll get is the back of Moscone Center.
