The bathrooms are in a rather weird place, down long hallways, almost as if it's in the next building.  But they are kept up fairly well.

Food:  Good food!  Our group of 5 (and a baby) ordered family style, 6 dishes, and we had food to spare.  They are pretty well sized portions.  I recommend the pad-thai and the ribs...very yummy.  And they can get very spicy for those of you who are sensitive to it.  And leave room for dessert...the fried bananas are to die for.  We paid ~$25/pp.

Service:  Very helpful...sometimes too helpful.  They constantly came by and re-filled still quite full glasses, cleared plates as soon as they were empty...as if we were kept under a watchful eye.  But it wasn't so intrusive to the point of annoying.

Conclusion:  Highly recommended thai food.  There are much better ones out there, but for the price I'd come back here over and over.
author: Jon D.

description:
Good everyday thai food that will quickly become your standard thai place if you live or work in the area.  

The curries and noodle dishes are delicious and will not disappoint.  

Decent ambiance and the prices are very reasonable.  I've never waited to eat here and they can accommodate groups.

If your reading this and craving thai food.... pick this spot.  Larb, spring roll, Pad Thai, duck curry, and a fish dish.  Trust me.
author: Mo P.

description:
Yummy vegetarian selection.  
Fast, great service too
author: Jenn B.

description: this place is always crowded around lunchtime when there are conventions going on, so i never thought i would go because i'm on a time crunch during lunchtime. So i figured i should at least try it once because i'm always going to the same places during lunch. I ordered some takeout by phone and got my order right away when i arrived (maybe they werent busy). I got the green curry with chicken. every thai curry seems to taste the same to me, so it's no difference for me. I was really hungry and maybe that was why its good but not much complaints since i ordered take out. the prices are average for thai also.
author: Marsha C.

description:
This place was great! And luckily... I happen to live right around the corner. 
Their basil tofu was great, so was their praram tofu. Their soft shell crab tempura was to die for! My roommate also said their salmon was delicious. The service was totally up to par and the best part: ITS NOT SUPER EXPENSIVE! Much better and cheaper, than osha thai.... my new favorite thai place!
author: Natasha T.

description:
Maybe there was a different cook staff there the night I went, because based on my experience, there is no way that this place deserves the 4-5 stars that some people have given.  

I got the BBQ Chicken dish - sorry, I don't remember what the real name is at the moment - and it was charred to a bitter crisp on the outside.  For $10, all you get are two pieces of burnt chicken with a few leaves that are supposed to resemble a salad.  There were at least 2 bone fragments in the chicken that I had to endure, and the "salad" was gone after about two forkfuls.  

On top of that, you have to pay extra for "jasmine rice", which is actually just regular rice that you would get for free at any other asian food place.  There was nothing "jasmine" about it.  

To summarize, this was one of those places where, as I walked out,  I felt like I had been scammed somehow.  

I would definitely recommend that you NOT go to this place.  Walk a bit more north and check out some of the restaurants up a few blocks away.
author: Matt P.

description:
I came to San Fran at the start of this year to work. I walked into the Cha Am as they have a bar at the front and I felt like a drink.
Well I have never experienced such hospitality. The bartender, the manager and the customers all said hello as I enjoyed a cold beer.
It is now May and I frequent this wonderfull establishment 2-4 times per week. The food is fantastic and the staff and customers are wonderful. A lady customer I met one night who used to be a regular sumed up this place, she called it the "international Cheers: and she is so correct. Thanks for making me feel so welcome and for providing fantastic Thai food.

Dave O

p.s. May want to consider doing a change to the music :-)
author: Dave O.

description:
Pretty solid and tasty Thai food.

I got the Pad Prik and it was darn good. Everything was very fresh and flavorful with good quality white chicken breast meat.

The lunch menu is very reasonable at like 8 bucks. The staff is very friendly.
Good option for lunch take-out.
author: Chili B.

description:
Oh curry...how I love thee! They make some delicious curries and stir fried dishes. Not to mention the yummy coconut ice cream. Droool.

Check it out, it's not too far from Osha.
author: Kitty N.

description: Delivery was quick. The food was so good. BBQ chicken was the best. Tom yum was top notch. Pad kee maw was standard. The wings were pretty good as well. And the thai ice tea was right now. I'm definitely ordering from them again!
author: Lynn L.

description: Fabulous meal of tempura soft shell crab, mango salad,chicken curry tofu curry pork chops, salad and mango sticky rice for five of us at a great price. Looking forward to our next time
author: Bruce D.

description: I was suggested this restaurant by my friend. We arrived here less than an hour before our movie started. The food here is very tasty, and pretty affordable. The food serving size was a little small. Otherwise, I'd give it 5 stars. We walked to the movie theater afterwards, and still had 15 minutes to spare.
author: eric g.

description:
We were shopping downtown, and got a craving for Thai food.  Parking after 6:00 PM was a cinch, during a weeknight.  We were greeted at the door and seated, promptly.  The service was attentive, but really wasn't very good at suggestions.  We chose from the specials board; choosing a shrimp/pumpkin dish, along with chicken coconut soup, and another chicken dish.  Very tasty, quite spicy, even though the server said it was mildly, spicy.  

The noise from a bunch of drinkers playing "liar's dice" at the bar was distracting.
author: Collin W.

description: placed a large order for our office. They delivered it, even a few minutes early. I had the kao pad, which was amazing. The thai iced tea was delicious as well. We will definitely order from them again.
author: Chas B.

description:
YUM!

I love this place for lunch. Its a bit pricey but ohhh so good. The spring rolls and gyoza are both awesome. I could eat a couple orders of each every day and be very happy. Fat, but happy.

Its not a very hip or trendy place as mentioned in some of the other reviews, but its intimate enough to take a date for a nice quiet lunch.
author: Aaron S.

description:
It's a Thai-owned Thai restaurant close to where I live!   Woohoo!!

I went inside to place a to-go order and was greeted by a server who took my order and offered me a glass of water and a table by the window.  Aw, how nice.  The pad kee-mow and pad thai were both good and get 4 stars!!  The restaurant is cozy, casual, and just what I was looking for.  I will definitely be back for more!
author: Nina L.

description: Lets start by saying my food arrived 2 hours after I ordered it. By then, it was ice cold and all the fried food was nasty and soggy. However, the prawn curry I had was still pretty good, and the bbq chicken was pretty good as well. I was just very bummed with the service and delivery. The guy didnt speak any english, and trying to explain to him where I lived was like pulling teeth. I dont think Ill order from here again given the thai choices in the city.
author: Steve S.

description: Good food at the pricier end of Thai. You do get nice ambiance, attentive service, and portions large enough for you to take home and enjoy some more.
author: Anthony W.

description: I definitely like their Pad See Ew here. It differs on days on whether it's better than Osha's across the street. I guess it just depends on the cook. But definitely a fave and only $8! What could be better than that?
author: Helen V.

description: great place close to where I work . I always ask what's good today and get a good recommendation from the waiter or waitress. Of course papaya salad is great, but seafood salad is tasty too. The chefs are all women and seem to have a handle on good thai food!
author: Jeff O.

description: I've ordered take-out here more than five times.  Almost every time they make my Pad See Ew and rice dish extremely sweet.  Mr. Chef, could you please lighten up the sugar/soy sauce/oyster sauce? Kthxbye.
author: Moko R.

description:
Steamed prawns were the draw, but after getting home, I was disappointed to discover that my salad had about four. Maybe five. It was a prawn letdown.

Still giving that third star because it was cheap and filling, but Cha Am could have been so much more.
author: Jason B.

description: The Pad See Ew and Crab Fried Rice are quite good here.  I was actually surprised since the first time I went there for dine-in the food wasn't that great nor was the service even though the place wasn't packed.  To be honest, I'm surprised it's still around considering when I walk by in the evenings the place is usually a quarter packed at best.  I'm not likely to dine-in here much but am likely to come back for take-out.
author: Kelvin V.

description:
Before I got to San Francisco I was pretty much determined that barring all else I was GOING to have some Asian food while I was in town. And of course my favorite being Thai I was on the lookout for someplace decent and hopefully within walking distance of the hotel (at the intersection of SOMA, Union Square, and the tip of the Tenderloin).

Came across Cha-Am on Folsom. Wish I had better things to say, but I was expecting a lot from a San Francisco Thai restaurant. I mean, hell... it should at least be better than the places I've been to in Texas, right?

Wrong. Cha-Am has an attractive seating area that gave me such high hopes for the food, but alas... it failed to deliver. I ordered my favorite Thai dishes... Pad Thai and Tom Ka Gai... cliche but I do not apologize. Anyway, EVERY Thai restaurant should be able to make an outstanding pad thai and coconut soup at a minimum. This was not the case. 

The Pad Thai was pretty damn good I'll admit. Although, I ordered it "extremely spicy" and it came to me "slightly spicy." Hey, that's not their fault. I just like things hot and I'm sure the chef in the back was afraid of pushing the envelope. But I was pleased with it. It had been a long Thai drought. Sadly, if I had only ordered the pad thai, I would have given the place four stars.

But the Tom Ka Gai I ordered as a starter was amateur at best. Thin, runny, oddly flavored, and not at all "put together." The bamboo shoots were stringy, tough, and inedible. The soup itself had no substance or texture. And no straw mushrooms. What were they thinking? I was so disappointed. 

On the other side of the table...

I'm more of a Gang-Ped person but my friend opted for the Kiew-Wan Gai. It tasted pretty good, but just like my disappointing soup, his curry was thin, runny, and didn't have that luscious texture a good curry typically has. (Or maybe I'm just spoiled by Mon's in San Antonio). 

Well my friend thought the curry was too spicy. Frankly, his dish was spicier than mine so we were thinking the waitress accidentally told the chef that the curry was supposed to be extremely spicy instead of the pad thai. Who knows.

Ultimately, my first San Francisco Thai experience was a bit disappointing. The prices were fair. The atmosphere was pretty good for a mid-priced Asian joint. But the food just didn't hit the mark.

It was a mixed bag. I'd eat there again, but I wouldn't be getting excited about it.
author: Michelle T.

description: Delicious thai food and the price is right! Great if you are working at the Moscone south it's right out back. Green curry chicken and rice mmm mmmmm good. Tamarind duck is very good too.
author: D J.

description: WARNING, UNSANITARY! I went here for lunch last Friday and found a BUG IN MY NOODLE CHICKEN SOUP! I was calm and asked the waitress to get the manager and she looked dumb-founded as if I was crazy, I showed her the bug and she walked away. I told her I wasn't paying for any of the food and she just told me in a very casual voice leaving was fine. I owe it to consumers to WARN you of their food. I WILL NEVER GO BACK HERE AGAIN! PLEASE TAKE CAUTION next time you eat here. I DO NOT ADVISE ON GOING HERE TO EAT EVER. A Food Inspection from the council is much needed, they should be shut down!
author: Nicole H.

description: We had several dishes recommended by the owner and they were all delicous.  These were some dishes I have never tried before except for the Pad Thai, and I am not that fond of curry but this curry dish was so good.  The veggies and eggplant plate was so yummy.  The service is good and fast, the food is delicous. The staff here is really friendly and helpful.
author: gordon g.

description: Luuuuuurv the eggplant salad!!! A tasty treat indeed!
author: Teena S.

description:
Have I stepped foot into this restaurant?  No
Does it matter?  Definitely not.
The best kind of dinner party to have is the kind where the host does no work...other than pick up to go food.  The host splits the cost of the food with the guests, which doesn't usually happen when the host is cooking, and clean up consists solely of sorting the recycling and placing the leftovers in Tupperware.  Easy Peezy.

Thai food was the food of choice for this particular dinner party, and Cha Am was the menu of choice.  Everything was awesome, and I'd pick this place to cook for my guests if it was my party for sure.  To start our meal, well...we will call them appetizers, but they were eaten amongst the other food as well...we had a chicken satay and delish Thai imperial roll.  The beef short ribs were cooked perfectly and like good dinner guests should, we shared appropriately.  The pad Thai was where I lost it, going back for thirds. The papaya salad was full of awesome prawns, and if it wasn't for the size of the party, I would have had more than one for sure.  We actually had to pull the Tom-ka-gai (coconut milk and chicken breast) out of one of the guests hands with brute force, and tell her to share...We had a yellow tofu curry, and a green curry that set everyone's mouths afire.  Apparently that was the one dish I didn't try, because I missed that flame.  I love feeling my food minutes after I eat it.  

This is just a touch too far for me to go for a FiDi lunch...and its too bad too, cuz id definitely come here sans dinner party.
author: Lauren F.

description: This place isn't a high-end thai place, in fact it's almost free. Combine that with the great, and, well, cheap drink menu, this place earns every one of it's four stars. A much value bet than Osha across the street.
author: Michael H.

description:
Things AK is not good at:
1. Sticking to plans
2. Being on time
3. Staying sober

Which is why 9:15 last night found me at the Chieftain, with Heidi, guzzling beer and talking smack instead of at Jason's, watching Donnie Darko and eating fabulous Thai food with my two favorite boys as planned.
I should not have had two Stellas (but thanks anyway, Pete!). If I had skipped that second Stella, I probably would have also skipped the Crystal Light, Sprite and Vodka cocktail (do not try this at home) at Jason's. Then I would have skipped the two beers I had after that. And if only I'd stayed sober, I probably wouldn't have talked through the movie, missed out on delicious Thai food, or woken up feeling like there was a demolition derby in my head.
I can not booze and eat simultaneously. And not enough time passed after my last drink last night to allow me to shove mass quantities of Cha-Am pad thai and satay down my throat before heading home. The bites I did have left me with what can only be described as primal desperation for another Cha-Am experience.
Which is why tonight's plans include me, a dark room, and all the Thai deliciousness my little stomach can hold.**
I will update after I finish cleaning myself up :)

**Unless Jason wants to invite me over for leftovers and a movie.
author: Autumn K.

description: This is our favorite thai place to go to. Usually once a week we'll dine in and enjoy our favorites. Pad gra pow, spicy noodle, or pad prik are the top favorites. Fast service, they take care of us regulars. Always fresh, unique and delicious specials as well. If you need a pick me up, try a thai iced tea or coffee. Portion sizes tend to be big, but if you are a big eater then they might be around just right/slightly too small. I usually can finish a whole lunch entree and have room left for a Starbucks drink on the way back.
author: Ryan D.

description: Pad-See-Ew here is fantastic. I usually come here during lunch, sit at the bar and my food is ready to go within 5 minutes of ordering.
author: Jon U.

description: Stopped by here last week for a quick bite during lunch with friends since we were craving Thai food.  I ordered the pad thai with chicken and I must say...I've definitely had MUCH better pad thai than this.  Even though my standards for Thai food are probably skewed since I was just in Thailand a few months ago BUT this could have been prepared much better.  The balance of sweet & savory was almost nonexistent, also their chicken tasted like rubber!  No joke!  I had one piece of the chicken and decided to just stick w/ the noodles.  I was going to give them a 2star rating but since the leftover still tasted decently after 2 days - I'll throw in an extra star in there.
author: Vivian W.

description: This place is close to our apartment, so we have eaten here several times.  The food is good and there are always tables available.  I like the Tom Yum soup and the spicier dishes on the menu.   Osha is only a few blocks away and I think they have better food (but much more crowded and louder).
author: Richard M.

description: another great little dinner place by default...all around decent thai food....very typical...nothing to go crazy about...it's good...and all the dishes i had so far were not bad at all....please do let us know if somebody finds a dish here that is spectacular....
author: Hen A.

description: Still one of my favorite Thai places.  The short ribs trumps the so-so service.  The basil beef is awesome.  Price is right!
author: Robert Y.

description:
We went here before the Yelp party at the supperclub.  There weren't a lot of dinner options in close proximity to the supperclub so it was either this or the Chaat Cafe around the corner.  This Thai food wasn't bad and the service was nice enough.  But the place reminded me of a bad 80's movie (perhaps early 90s?)...We are talking dropped fluorescent lights in hyper color colors.  Everything inside was designed quite odd and my table's energy (i.e.: evening enthusiasm) didn't seem to jive with the over all atmosphere of the place (quiet ennui).  In fact, for a while it was just the two of us and one other party of two.  After a while a couple more people showed up.
I just think it is a weird location.  It is sorta close to some downtown things but not close enough to down town things to get a steady influx of people.
I got what I tend to always get at Thai places: the yellow curry.  The steak kabob things we got were much too rubbery for my taste.
author: Lauren S.

description: Although, it's less popular than the "other" thai place that is on 2nd street, I will still come here to Cha -Am for some quick and easy takeout. In fact, for a long time, it was the only thai place in the area for several years. Their pad thai see-u with tofu is delish. And the ga-pao (spicy) tofu will make you melt. The wait is never that long and the service is very quick and friendly. If you are craving thai food and need it quick, opt for Cha-Am.
author: Jan Z.

description: The Pad Thai's sauce was a little tomato-heavy. The water tasted good. For some reason I just don't feel like Yelping much about this corner joint. Oh look, Bong Su is right across the street! Mmmm.
author: Daniel C.

description: The best Thai food in Berkeley comes to SF. The sister restaurant in Berkeley is always packed and everyone considers it the best Thai around. I think the food at the SF restaurant is not quite as good but still worth trying. It's better for lunch than dinner. The service is less than stellar and it can get pretty cold inside at night.
author: Aaron V.

description: The food was OK, nothing special out of the ordinary.  The service was great though, very attentive.  What irked me was the wierd atmosphere.  There were older people here mostly dressed up and they were playing american music.  It just made it kind of stale and wierd for me.  Is it because of this location in town that pulls the older crowd here?  Not really sure about this one.  I kinda felt like I was back in New Jersey ;)
author: Mitch A.

description: Decent choice for lunch in SOMA.  I had the green curry chicken with a thai iced tea.  It was definitely good, but not on par with other Thai places in the city.  Also, the service wasn't that great, so I'll give it 3 stars.
author: Chris Q.

description: Decent Thai.  Friendly service.  Always a seat available.
author: Amme P.

description: Pretty good Thai food -- good soups, curries, etc.  They tend to have room if you're looking for somewhere last minute, and take-out is convenient.  It's fine, and prices are fairly reasonable especially for the neighborhood.
author: Leo C.

description:
I think this place is ok but my colleagues dig it.
Curries and pad thai, pad see ow are all so-so.  

Much better places on Clement, Geary and Haight.
author: WP D.

description:
Good food if your hungry and take a group out to .  Their short ribs are very good along with their salads.  Good location at a prime spot on a corner.  But their is a reason I just gave them two stars: the service.  Its one thing to serve your customers with no enthusiasm which can be understandable probably because they are disgruntled but its another thing give us food from the floor.  
I was out with my co-workers over here for lunch because one of them was leaving the company.  We ordered some dumplings I believe and as the waiter was about give us the dumplings, about three of the dumplings fell onto the floor and the waiter picked it up and put it back on the plate and served those dumplings to us, with the waiter smiling.  All of my co-workers just looked at each other and was shocked that our waiter just did that.  Later on, one of us had ordered salad and a different waiter was about to come by with the salad and did the same thing the other waiter did, she dropped about a portion of the salad, pick it up, and served it to my co-worker.  I dont know if the waiters were going to have a lunch break or something because they seemed to be in a hurry but you should not serve food that was obviously dropped onto the floor.  I think its common courtesy for them to go back and bring another set of whatever you ordered.
author: Kris A.

description: We (my friend and I) chose this place to catch up and discuss business in private. It was virtually empty when we walked in at noon, but quickly filled up. The noise level grew as did the seeming impatience of the wait staff. We felt we needed to order quickly or we would be gumming up the works. We chose a couple of items from the menu, including one listed as "spicy". The food arrived on the coolish side and the spicy dish was not at all.  I think if we had taken the time to choose wisely, I might have been more satisfied. Still, the price was right so I didn't feel "cheated" when I left. I would try this place again, but I have a hard time imagining it becoming a favorite.
author: Chris W.

description:
This is a decent Thai place.  Some dishes are better than others, but generally you should be satisfied.  My favorite Thai dishs are Panang curry, Tom Kha Gai soup (coconut milk soup with chicken), Pud Thai, Ginger Beef and Chicken Satay. They make all of these dishes pretty decently, except for the Pud Thai, which I don't really care for (the noodles seem low quality).
I'm giving four stars because I am judging it against a scale of all types of food.  Thai seems to be more consistent (it is very hard to find a really good or bad Thai place), so this run-of-the-mill Thai place deserves four stars overall.  If I were judging it against just Thai places, I would probably give it three stars.
The places seems clean and the wait staff is pretty friendly.  The price point is fair although certainly not inexpensive.
Ask for the Prik Ki Nu chilis-- they will be surprised that you know of them and delighted to serve them.  They are super spicy, delicious, and definitely a sign of a solid Thai place!
author: Joe M.

description: Went here sunday night because i eat out too much. my friend nate loves this place so he suggested we come here after jesse and i shot down a bunch of other suggestions. thai is safe. the inside looks like a bickfords. do you have bickfords here?  ok, an ihop. i dont know, its a generic place with horrible MUZAK playing. there wasnt a whole lot of interesting looking things to choose from. i had thai iced tea and green curry pork. it was ok nothing special. jesse agreed with me with his curry. the best thing about this restaurant happened after. i accidentally left my phone there cuz im a ditz and they called jesse and told him.  they very nicely held my phone (since they were closed by then) and i went and picked it up in the morning. yay they could have stolen it or anything but they didnt! so good customer service, bad decor, mediocre food.
author: Merredith L.

description: Love their BBQ chicken! These folks used to be on Kearny and it was a great place with excellent food at a cheap price for a takeout lunch. Now that they have moved to SOMA I don't get there as often but if I am in SOMA I will always stop in for the chicken.
author: Maggie M.

description: Its pricey, and not what it advertises.  I have previously been satisfied with the yellow curry, but this time I got a wide noodle seafood dish ($9.75) which purported to have scallops, shrimp and calamari, and only had bay scallops.  This kind of shocked me actually.  This was To Go, so don't have time to go back and get a refund (or get those shrimp!)  I recommend going to the Dim Sum joint a block farther down, they have tons of shrimp and aren't stingy with it.
author: Jane S.

description:
i was confused to who our waiter was not because they all look the same, but because there were 3 or 4 different people doing things for our table and the tables surrounding us. i literally had to raise my hand and figure out which waiter to wave down to get a glass of water, or to order my food, or order a drink, or get a refill... (if you catch my drift). as many servers as their are you would be surprised of how many of them are just walking around and not really doing anything to help you.

when the food came, it was really good. i finish all my red curry salmon and brown rice. i had my usual thai ice tea. my son had a coconut mushroom tofu soup, that he didn't like, so my co-worker gave him some of his crab fried rice. 

when it came to the leftovers, i SWARE TO GOD, i asked 3 different servers for a box for leftovers at least 2 times each, and NEVER got a togo box. the soup my son didn't like, i really wanted for dinner. but i had to just say fu(k it and leave it because my co-workers had to get back to work. 

my co-worker, who's been here many times before said that the service has ALWAYS been pretty bad. 

so good food, horrible service. i need to make a decision to if i'll ever come back to this place...
author: Renae C.

description: This is my favorite thai place in the city - I've never been disappointed.
author: sara s.

description: Pretty good thai, and we used to eat there once a week for lunch.  But one day, I found a fly in my soup.  Completely grossed me out.  A huge fly, too.    So I boycotted this place for a couple months, and then we decided to try it again.  Haven't seen another fly, but I still inspect everything I order really well.  Otherwise the food I've had there is always yummy.
author: Toni G.

description: Located right by the SF MOMA, I have been here on several occasions and really like the joint. Nice staff who check up on you regularly and make you feel welcomed. Their curries are excellent, pick your poison but the Massaman was succulent and hot, just the way it was intended to be. Their Tom Ka soup is fantastic, which is always a good measuring point for the overall quality of the restaurant. Their Pad Se Lew is equally as impressive, and warrants a taste. Do it.
author: Kenny G.

description: Decent Thai food.  Your favorite color of curry is the obvious choice, but grilled chicken and grilled fish are surprisingly not bad.  Open on Sunday afternoon.
author: Russel S.

description: At first, you think: "Sweet, Thai food right down the street!" Then you realize they only have one particularly good dish, which is the tofu and veggie thing (the first item in the vegetarian section). That dish is a great way to get your vegetable fix.
author: Ellie P.

description: I always liked the Thai food here.  Dependable, and there's always a free table.
author: Katherine W.

description: Okay, decent Thai food.  Easily forgettable.
author: Brandon B.

description: Pretty standard Thai food. Mediocre service even when the place was practically empty! Definitely a cheaper alternative to Osha considering the portions are huge for the price. It's not stellar, but it's not bad either. Three stars.
author: Natalie T.

description: Cha Am is your run of the mill Thai joint. Decent enough to be put in rotation on the office lunch schedule. Coconut soup seems to be a standout.
author: Philip M.

description:
lol.  i walked in there and was like "oh what the hell?"  the place looked like something from the 60s with neon lights at the ceiling and flashy pastel paint colors.  it's almost as bad as King of Thai noodles.

i came here for lunch and got their Red Curry with Prawns and Pumpkin ($8.95).  I'm a huge fan of pumpkin.  i thought it was very good except it was just a little too spicy for me.  i would have enjoyed it more if i didn't think my mouth was dying a little each time i ate some curry.  Next time i'll tell them not so hot; it was just unexpected for me.
author: H. L.

description: Not too far from Market and the Metreon, this is a pretty decent restaurant. I recommend the som tum (papaya salad). Service is sometimes a little sketchy, but I'll be going back for the food.
author: Kevin K.

description: This place is OK, but I would much rather go to a million other thai spots. I was not a fan of their curry. The service was spotty and it took forever to get my bill, which, when you are on a lunch break, is aggravating. I'd honestly rather go to King of Thai on Jesse & 5th.
author: Zac H.

description:
I'm super picky about Thai food (have had a bad experience with a roommate that used to order really bad stinky Thai food and let it rot in his room).  Anyway...this place is delicious--my favorite Thai springs rolls ever.
We called without a menu and named off a bunch of our favorite dishes--some made to special order.  Waitstaff and chef were really accommodating, food was delicious and not too greasy...and really reasonably priced (like $60 for 4 ppl).  I'm so glad to have gotten over my Thai food fears--thanks Cha-Am!
author: Amy C.

description: I just had the pad-thai but it was only so-so.  I'd return to try some other things, but wouldn't go if you're set on pad-thai
author: Lauren V.

description: When I worked in downtown SF, this was a nice escape with a girlfriend for lunch. It's got a great atmosphere, and you can people watch if you sit near the windows. The coconut milk soup and the golden triangles are making my mouth water as I type this. It's not slick, but it's the real deal for Thai food, and especially Thai coffee or tea. It's not cheap, but I'd say it's on par with what you expect to pay for white tablecloths. You won't break the bank, but you'll drop a little coin. Good place to take a client too if you want to get off the beaten path and they are down to earth. You won't be embarrassed.
author: Safiya N.

description: Everyone has pretty much the right idea about this place. Its average, nothing great, but not bad. Thai Iced tea is same, prices are decent - Get the lunch menu - way cheaper and still filling. The good thing about this place though is that you can bring a lot of people, which makes sense why its next to Metreon.
author: Mike B.

description: Yes.  It is another typical Thai restaurant, but there's nothing wrong with that.  They have some very tasty dishes and location is very close to where I live.  the Lad-na-talay on the lunch menu was sooooo good.  it comes with sauteed seafood and greens and garlic sauce.  and they actually gives you a lot of seafood instead just a bunch of noodles!  I wish it opens on Sunday though.
author: Vivian H.

description: They used to have these brown noodles (chow mein type) that I loved but I don't see it on the menu anymore. Boo!

This place is great! The service is soo friendly and helpful and the restaurant is cozy and casual. Not crazy-noisy like other restaurants can get!  They have a full bar too.  We had a little party there last weekend and the waitstaff and owners were super nice and accommodating!  The food was tasty and fresh so everyone was full and happy!!  I will come here for lunch or dinner whenever I'm in the area!
author: Amy H.

description: It's good, well priced authentic food, in a casual setting.  It doesn't rate high on the swank/style meter, but that's what nice about this place.  It's unpretentious and the servers are attentive and friendly.
author: Naomi N.

description:
Herre Gud how can they call this Thai food? I have not been to their Berkeley location, but this experience was a turn-off. The Tom-Ka-Gai and Tom-Ka-J soups should have been the same minus the chicken or tofu. The chicken version came with galanga and lemon grass, the tofu version had huge chucks of tofu with no spicy leaves or much else. It seems they just have big pots of ingredients and spoon the contents haphazardly into the soup bowls as it gets ordered.
The beef salad came on a bed of mixed greens like you get in bulk bags. Many of the leaves were already rotting, and the overly raw beef tasted as if it was seasoned only when the salad was assembled and not while cooking. The crab special was essentially a large shell overflowing with mostly rice, bits of crab, frozen peas and a couple of slices of tomato and cucumber. It had 2 springs of cilantro on top and a bunch of parsely for garnish????? And not cheap either.
We had to beg for tea and water, and strangely, we were served with the normal fork and spoon traditional to Thai food, but the large group seated next to us was served with chopsticks. The experience was like eating at one of those awful Chinatown restaurants that serve you veggies with square carrots straight out of the freezer. If you go to their website and click on the menu, you're going to see some beautiful food but don't be fooled.  Too many other good Thai joints in SF to bother with this one.
author: OffToRio B.

description: They're really nice here, more low-key than the harried Osha Thai on 2nd (which is overrated, imho). I always find fresh and tasty meals here.
author: elsa m.

description: This place is speedy and delicious. I am a simple Thai-lovin girl, and usually just get Pad Thai. Cha-Am's dish is super good. Prices are good too, so a perfect place for a lunch date or meeting.
author: Allison B.

description: Solid dishes, with a few well above average: try the spicy tofu.
author: nick w.

description: We like going to this restaurant because it's casual/quiet/relaxing and the food is family style.  We like their Sa-Tay,  Tom-Ka-Gai Soup, Tamarind-Duck and Ga-Pao-Tofu.  Their curry dishes are also excellent!
author: JenJen W.

description: This place used to be really good but not any more. In fact the curries really sucked. The service was good, I didn't like the curry and they replaced it with noddles but even that wasn't good.
author: Maya G.

description: I like this place.  It's in my neighborhood and fairly inexpensive, plus the food is good.  Admittedly, I am fairly conservative in ordering and stick to Pad Thai and curry dishes, but have not been disappointed.  The decor is nice and it's clean.  They have a full bar as well.
author: Debbie W.

description: Friendly staff. The are able to make dishes with or without fish-sauce. Have many veggie options. Will definitely go again.
author: Priya K.

description: I remember the Berkeley restaurant to be rather tasty, so we decided to give the SF one a go. Not a good idea: the food was sub-par. The pad thai was an electric orange, which seemed to match the 80's decor and Kenny  G. background music. The green curry had a nice flavor, but the meat inside was rather suspect.
author: GS M.

description:
I don't know what to say... I don't know how many times I will give this restaurant a chance...

Despite the convenience of it being right across the street and my occassional craving for fried tofu-

The service straight up SUCKS!!!!!!! Plain and simple.

I mean, the staff is nice but, look forward to spending a good 3 hours for dinner. I'd probably get to shoot to the closest asian market, pick up tofu and fry that sucker myself faster than they can serve it to me on a plate. 

If you don't mind the wait, their food is actually very good. 

I've been forced to tip close to nothing each time, but my tips have risen, just because I feel sorry for them!
author: James A.

description: Entrees don't come with rice so you will have to shell out an extra $1.50 for a dinky scoop of rice!!! wth!
author: Phil Q.

description: Cha-am was pretty busy on the Friday night we dropped in, but after moving in nearby we decided to give it a go.  We found the food to be excellent and the prices to be reasonable, but struggled to give the place a higher rating.  Our menu consisted of the mixed appetizer plate (sizeable, good variety), a green chicken curry (loved the chili) and a fantastic chicken/shrimp/glass noodle salad from the special list (VERY tasty!).  Our waiter was pleasant enough but almost seemed to be learning the job - attracting his attention for a second drink was challenging!  That said, we definitely saw enough for us to give Cha-Am another go.
author: Nigel G.

description: My uncle loves Thai food and my sister used to live their and they both like this place - I think it's as good as any other of the million or so Thai places that have cropped up in SF over the last five years...
author: Quartknee K.

description: Had lunch yesterday at Cha-Am in the city. Very expensive, I was hungry afterwards. First, the specials menu said the dish was a clay pot. The waiter asked if I wanted white or brown rice. I asked if it came with it since the claypot was a noodle dish. He tells me yes.When it came it was on a plate. I said - Where's the claypot?? Oh - that's only for dinner. The brown rice was $1 extra.  What a waste of $12 with tax and tip. The food was ok - nothing special, that's for sure. I've been to Cha-Am in Berkeley and I don't remember any issues like this.
author: Michelle G.

description: This is my favorite Thai restaurant in SF -- very reasonable prices, a nice interior and great people working here.  Oddly, they also have a small bar that has a friendly bartender and patrons -- great place to have a beer while waiting for takeout.  I usually get one of their curry dishes or pad thai, but they also offer some excellent and unusual specials.  The tom kha gai soup is also outstanding.
author: Ed K.

description: the normal menu is forgettable, but the higher priced specials menu will stretch the capabilities of your tongue with contrasting flavors and textures.  delicious.  neon lit and generally empty (no wait!).  lacks the treehouse charm of its sister restaurant in berkeley.
author: Teresa Z.

description: We dropped in before an event at Yerba Buena.  There were only about 2 or 3 other parties there, but service was amazingly slow.  Finally our server approached and had a very short attitude, like we were imposing on him.  He took our order and started to walk away, and we asked if we were to give him our drink order, or go to the bar.  He said he'd take it, but never came back to do so.  Also never checked after we were served to see how we were doing.  The food was nothing to write about (bland, with watery sauce). We were nice to him regardless, but left no tip.   As an aside, the bartender was great and very nice!!
author: Rebecca S.

description: Impressively fresh vegetables. The service was beyond attentive. Unasked, the waiter brought more sauce that we liked from an appetizer. Water glasses were attentively filled. . We ordered 3 things on the menu. Each was distinctive and markedly different from the others. All were fantastic.  The prices were so low. The whole package is too good to last. I've been to Bangkok and I know Thai food. Arroy maak.
author: T W.

description: I've gotten takeout here once because it was conveniently located.  The order was ready on time.  But pad thai was bland.  Green papaya salad was pretty good, on the spicy side, but the papaya wasn't julienned completely, which is pretty uncommon in my experience (and I order a lot of green papaya salad).  "Thai Imperial Rolls" (the fried spring rolls) were OK, but kind of dense inside in the way that makes me think they were either previously frozen or made a while ago.  It's kind of hard to go wrong with deep fried rolls though.  The sauce that came with the rolls was a chili sauce but was kind of goopy and sweet, sort of like a spicy "duck sauce" (that orange sauce you sometimes get at Chinese restaurants).  Seems like a solid neighborhood place, but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here.
author: Gina C.

description: Haven't eaten there in a while. But the food's alright. More about atmosphere there. Although, everytime I've gone there it's been a little empty. Still, I'd go back.
author: perry c.

description: nice painting, cheap food, good location.  lots of the food looked good, but too bad the pad thai had ketchup in it :(
author: Peter H.
